CZ_NAME: UPPER SANTA CRUZ RIVER AND ALTAR VALLEYS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures were recorded across southeast Arizona on August 27th.  One heat-related fatality occurred in southeast Pima County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Above normal temperatures occurred in southeast Arizona on August 27th.  High temperatures included 105 degrees at the Tucson International Airport, 107 degrees at Sells and 104 degrees (record high) at Sasabe.  The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one adult male 11 miles south of Three Points.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures developed across the lower deserts of central Arizona in early June with highs in the Phoenix area climbing into the upper 90s and eventually reaching triple digits by June 5th. Despite high temperatures only reaching to near seasonal normals (and falling well short of excessive heat warning thresholds) it proved hot enough to be fatal to an elderly man whose car became stuck in desert sand stranding him without water or shade. The Maricopa County Sheriff's Office indicated that their helicopter spotted the man's vehicle stranded in sand on Gila River Indian land near Sun Lakes. Authorities found his body at 1340MST on Thursday June 6th; he was deceased. The sheriff's office indicated that the death was likely due to heat exposure.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During the first week of June high temperatures over the deserts were near to slightly below seasonal normal, but did finally reach into the triple digits by Wednesday June 5th. Despite highs being near normal (and well below excessive heat warning thresholds) they were sufficient to lead to a fatality in the deserts to the south of Phoenix. According to the Maricopa County Sheriff's Office, their helicopter spotted the vehicle of a World War 2 veteran stuck in soft sand on Gila River Indian land south of Phoenix at 1340MST Thursday June 6th. The 97 year old veteran had died due to exposure and dehydration. He had been missing for several days before being discovered on Thursday.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Oppressive temperatures in the mid 90's to around 100 degrees along with dew point readings in the mid to upper 70's produced very dangerous heat conditions with heat index readings in excess of 105 degrees for much of the afternoon and early evening.||Some of the more extreme heat index readings experienced during the afternoon included 113 degrees at Wagner, 112 degrees at Le Mars, Canton and Mitchell, 111 degrees at Cherokee, Sioux City, Huron and Yankton, 110 degrees at Sioux Falls, Colton and White Lake, and 109 degrees near Beaver Creek.

Strong high pressure over the Desert Southwest near the end of the month led excessive heat warning conditions for parts of the region. The deadly heat resulted in 25 fatalities (20 direct and 5 indirect) according to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two indirect fatalities were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender and circumstances unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures led to paramedics responding to multiple heat related emergencies.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Paramedics responded to six separate emergencies due to the heat.  Patients called 911 complaining of dizziness, dehydration, fatigue and nausea.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat indices peaked between 108 and 117 degrees across southeast Missouri during the afternoon hours. Along and southeast of a line from Poplar Bluff to Sikeston, the heat index peaked from 110 to 117 degrees. Elsewhere across southeast Missouri, the peak heat index was just under 110. Actual air temperatures reached the lower to mid 90's.  Dew points were in the upper 70's to near 80, which resulted in the very high heat indices. At mid levels of the atmosphere, a large ridge of high pressure dominated the southern half of the United States. A weak surface warm front over the lower Ohio Valley caused dew points to pool into the upper 70's to near 80.

Very hot temperatures were experienced in parts of southeast Arizona on June 12th and 13th with high temperatures nearing or equaling established records. Two heat-related fatalities occurred--one in western Pima County and another on the Tohono O'odham Nation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Well above normal temperatures occurred in southeast Arizona June 12th and 13th. Respective high temperatures were 111 (record tied) and 109 degrees at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, 110 and 112 (record tied) degrees at Ajo and 108 degrees both days at Sells. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals.  One was a female child who perished on the 12th just north of the International Border west of Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument. The second was an adult female who died on the 13th northwest of Sells on the Tohono O'odham Nation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced in parts of southeast Arizona on June 12th and 13th with high temperatures nearing or equaling established records. Two heat-related fatalities occurred--one in western Pima County and another on the Tohono O'odham Nation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Well above normal temperatures occurred in southeast Arizona June 12th and 13th. Respective high temperatures were 111 (record tied) and 109 degrees at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, 110 and 112 (record tied) degrees at Ajo and 108 degrees both days at Sells. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals.  One was a female child who perished on the 12th just north of the International Border west of Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument. The second was an adult female who died on the 13th northwest of Sells on the Tohono O'odham Nation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat indices peaked between 105 and 112 degrees across most of western Kentucky except the Owensboro and Henderson area during the afternoon hours. The highest heat indices were over the Mississippi River counties, where the peak heat index ranged from 110 to 112 degrees. Actual air temperatures reached the lower to mid 90's. Dew points were in the mid 70's to near 80, which resulted in the very high heat indices. At mid levels of the atmosphere, a large ridge of high pressure dominated the southern half of the United States. A weak surface warm front over the lower Ohio Valley caused dew points to pool into the mid 70's to near 80.

A very large high in the upper levels of the atmosphere was sprawled across the southern two-thirds of the country for several days. This high brought four days of oppressive heat and humidity across southwest Indiana. Afternoon heat indices peaked between 100 and 104 degrees each day from the 18th to the 21st. The heat index at Evansville peaked at 100 degrees on the 18th, and 102 to 103 from the 19th to the 21st. Just prior to this heat wave, the remnants of Tropical Storm Barry produced a widespread soaking rain that set the stage for very high humidity levels. Dew points were in the mid to upper 70's. Actual high temperatures were mostly in the lower 90's.

Just prior to this heat wave, the remnants of Tropical Storm Barry produced a widespread soaking rain that set the stage for very high humidity levels. Dew points were in the mid to upper 70's. Actual high temperatures were mostly in the lower 90's.

A very large high in the upper levels of the atmosphere was sprawled across the southern two-thirds of the country for several days. This high brought four days of oppressive heat and humidity across southwest Indiana. Afternoon heat indices peaked between 100 and 104 degrees each day from the 18th to the 21st. The heat index at Evansville peaked at 100 degrees on the 18th, and 102 to 103 from the 19th to the 21st. Just prior to this heat wave, the remnants of Tropical Storm Barry produced a widespread soaking rain that set the stage for very high humidity levels. Dew points were in the mid to upper 70's. Actual high temperatures were mostly in the lower 90's.

Along and northwest of a line from Owensboro to Murray, heat indices peaked between 101 and 107 degrees during the afternoon hours. A combination of temperatures in the mid 90's and dew points in the mid 70's produced these hazardous heat indices. A southwest wind flow of hot and humid air ahead of a cold front was responsible for this first potentially dangerous heat event of the season.

Cal OSHA reported a heat related illness in Pleasanton on the 24th. Afternoon high temperature at the Livermore airport was 92 degrees. Many locations across the interior were in the low 90s with some coastal locations even reaching the 80s. Three daily record high temperatures were either tied or broken.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cal OSHA reported a heat related illness in Pleasanton on the 24th. Afternoon high temperature at the Livermore airport was 92 degrees. Time estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One man died in Las Vegas of heat related causes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One man died in Las Vegas of heat related causes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A heat wave gripped northwestern Connecticut from July 19th through the 21st. Temperatures soared to the mid-90s with dewpoints in the low to mid-70s. This resulted in heat index values in the 100 to 110 range in the warmest areas. Saturday, July 20th was the hottest day for most areas. Due to the excessive heat, cooling centers were opened and pool hours were extended.

A heat wave gripped eastern New York from July 19th through the 21st. Temperatures soared into the low to mid-90s with dewpoints in the low to mid-70s. This resulted in heat index values in the 100 to 110 range in the warmest spots of the Hudson Valley. Saturday, July 20th was the hottest day for most areas. Due to the excessive heat, area cities extended hours for pools and cooling centers, and Saturday's races at the Saratoga Race Course were cancelled due to the heat for the first time since August 2006.||The hot and humid airmass provided fuel for thunderstorms that formed along the Lake Ontario shoreline during the late afternoon of the 20th. Two clusters of storms moved from the Mohawk Valley through the Capital District and into the Taconics during the evening, resulting in several reports of wind damage. The storms knocked out power to over 1,700 customers in Schenectady and Saratoga Counties.

A heat wave gripped southern Vermont from July 19th through the 21st. Temperatures soared to near 90 with dewpoints in the low to mid-70s. This resulted in heat index values in the 95 to 100 range in the warmest valleys. Saturday, July 20th was the hottest day for most areas. Due to the excessive heat, cooling centers were opened, and an outdoor festival in Brattleboro was postponed to September.

Persistent southwest winds and the passage of a warm front brought a heat wave to southern WI. The Milwaukee and Madison areas did experience an influx of emergency room visits due to heat exhaustion and/or heat stroke.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Maximum heat index values of 100 to 110 degrees Fahrenheit. Dane County Emergency Management reported 39 visits to the emergency rooms across the county with 8 people admitted for heat exhaustion or heat stroke.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index reached 107 degrees at Muscle Shoals.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large ridge of high pressure building over the Midwest brought a period of hot and humid weather to central Illinois from July 17th through July 21st.  High temperatures routinely topped out in the lower to middle 90s during that time frame, while overnight lows only cooled into the middle to upper 70s.  High relative humidity values helped push maximum afternoon heat index values to 105 degrees or higher.  A cold front eventually brought relief to areas along and west of I-55 by July 21st...with cooler conditions not arriving further east until the 22nd.  Due to the prolonged period of excessive heat and humidity, two people died across central Illinois.  An 81-year old man in Flora in Clay County passed away on July 18th, while a 61-year old woman died in Peoria on July 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An 81-year old man died of heatstroke while doing outdoor yard work in Flora in Clay County on July 18th.

Heat indices soared into the 90 to 100 degree range in the Capital District and Mid-Hudson Valley on the 30th, prompting the issuance of Heat Advisories. Scattered thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening as a cold front interacted with the hot and humid airmass. Several of these storms became severe, resulting in wind damage. Falling trees and wires resulted in power outages with 6,700 customers losing power in Saratoga County, 1,900 in Warren County, and around 4,000 in the Catskill/Leeds area. One person in Warren County was injured when a tree fell on an RV.

Scattered thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening as a cold front interacted with the hot and humid airmass. Several of these storms became severe, resulting in wind damage. Falling trees and wires resulted in power outages with 6,700 customers losing power in Saratoga County, 1,900 in Warren County, and around 4,000 in the Catskill/Leeds area. One person in Warren County was injured when a tree fell on an RV.

A heat wave gripped eastern New York from July 19th through the 21st. Temperatures soared into the low to mid-90s with dewpoints in the low to mid-70s. This resulted in heat index values in the 100 to 110 range in the warmest spots of the Hudson Valley. Saturday, July 20th was the hottest day for most areas. Due to the excessive heat, area cities extended hours for pools and cooling centers, and Saturday's races at the Saratoga Race Course were cancelled due to the heat for the first time since August 2006.||The hot and humid airmass provided fuel for thunderstorms that formed along the Lake Ontario shoreline during the late afternoon of the 20th. Two clusters of storms moved from the Mohawk Valley through the Capital District and into the Taconics during the evening, resulting in several reports of wind damage. The storms knocked out power to over 1,700 customers in Schenectady and Saratoga Counties.

As surface high pressure moved offshore, southerly flow brought increasing warmth and humidity, combining to create heat index values in excess of 105 degrees in portions of southern Maryland.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values exceeded 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure shifted east into the Ark-La-Tex on June 21st, and persisted through the 22nd, resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid 90s area-wide each day. When combined with the high humidity due to little mixing of dewpoints, afternoon heat indices ranged between 105-110 degrees each day across Southwest Arkansas. Little relief was found at night, with temperatures only briefly falling into the mid and upper 70s. Cooler temperatures due to a complex of  showers and thunderstorms ahead of an upper level trough and associated weak cold front moved through the area on the 23rd, providing relief to the oppressive heat for the remainder of the month.

An upper level ridge of high pressure shifted east into the Ark-La-Tex on June 21st, and persisted through the 22nd, resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid 90s area-wide each day. When combined with the high humidity due to little mixing of dewpoints, afternoon heat indices ranged between 105-110 degrees each day across Southwest Arkansas. Little relief was found at night, with temperatures only briefly falling into the mid and upper 70s. Cooler temperatures due to a complex of  showers and thunderstorms ahead of an upper level trough and associated weak cold front moved through the area on the 23rd, providing relief to the oppressive heat for the remainder of the month.

Very hot temperatures were experienced in parts of southeast Arizona on June 29th and 30th with several new record high temperatures established. Three heat-related fatalities occurred on the Tohono O'odham Nation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Well above normal temperatures occurred in southeast Arizona June 29th and 30th. Respective high temperatures were 112 and 111 degrees (both new records) at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, 110 and 112 (new record) degrees at Ajo, 112 (new record) and 107 degrees at Sells, 109 degrees both days (record tied and new record) at Sasabe, and 105 and 104 degrees (both records) at Nogales Airport.  The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three adult males during this time frame near Topawa on the Tohono O'odham Nation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure prevailed over California between June 10 and June 12 which resulted in much warmer than normal temperatures across the area during the period. High temperatures generally ranged between 102 and 107 degrees each day across much of the San Joaquin Valley prompting the first Excessive Heat Warning of the season. As a result of the heat, emergency cooling centers were opened each afternoon in several municipalities in the San Joaquin Valley during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 102 and 107 degrees at most locations between June 10 and June 12.

More than a week of excessive heat across the Rio Grande Valley was a likely culprit in at least four deaths of undocumented immigrants who perished from heat stroke or severe heat exhaustion as well as dehydration in brush just south of McAllen, Texas, on June 23rd. The heat was the result of persistent atmospheric high pressure centered over central Texas, with low level southerly flow providing enhanced tropical moisture via exceptional dew point temperatures, even during the afternoon. The period of excessive heat was from June 17 through 24, so more fatalities may have occurred in the Rio Grande Valley during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A New York Times article described potential heat-related deaths, as provided by United States Border Patrol (USBP), during the afternoon of June 23, 2019, in the brush inside the levee along the Rio Grande south of McAllen. One woman (age unknown but assumed to be in her 20s) and three children (two infants and a toddler) were pronounced dead when found that evening. Between 3 and 4 PM CDT, the heat index at McAllen/Miller Airport, less than 10 miles north of the location of the bodies and the most relevant proxy location, reported more than an hour of heat index of 118 degrees.  Excessive heat is defined as values 116 or higher in the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following a period of much below normal temperatures and frequent rainfall during the second half of May as an unseasonably cool airmass prevailed over the area, temperatures rose to above seasonal levels by early June. High pressure strengthened over the area on June 5 resulting in the first day of widespread triple digit heat prompting the first Heat Advisory of the season for much of the San Joaquin Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 100 and 104 degrees at most locations on June 5.

CZ_NAME: SANTA CLARA VALLEY INCLUDING SAN JOSE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of high pressure and strong offshore flow resulted in an early season heat wave across the Bay Area from June 9th to the 11th. Multiple daily records were broken across the region and multiple power outages were reported due to the heat. Approximately 26,000 people across the region lost power on Monday followed by an additional 30,000 on Tuesday. Three fatalities were reported during the heat event. One man died as a direct result of heat related illness while two others drowned while attempting to cool down during the heat wave. Hot temperatures and dry grass resulted in a vegetation fire that spread to a residence.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Santa Clara County medical examiner announced the death of an 83 year old man found in front of his home due to heat. Time unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure and a very dry air mass made for hot conditions over southwest Oregon during this interval.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported low temperatures ranged from 49 to 70 degrees. Reported high temperatures ranged from 88 to 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure prevailed over California between June 10 and June 12 which resulted in much warmer than normal temperatures across the area during the period. High temperatures generally ranged between 102 and 107 degrees each day across much of the San Joaquin Valley prompting the first Excessive Heat Warning of the season. As a result of the heat, emergency cooling centers were opened each afternoon in several municipalities in the San Joaquin Valley during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 102 and 107 degrees at most locations between June 10 and June 12.

Cooler temperatures due to a complex of  showers and thunderstorms ahead of an upper level trough and associated weak cold front moved through the area on the 23rd, providing relief to the oppressive heat for the remainder of the month.

An upper level ridge of high pressure shifted east into the Ark-La-Tex on June 21st, and persisted through the 22nd, resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid 90s area-wide each day. When combined with the high humidity due to little mixing of dewpoints, afternoon heat indices ranged between 105-110 degrees each day across Southwest Arkansas. Little relief was found at night, with temperatures only briefly falling into the mid and upper 70s. Cooler temperatures due to a complex of  showers and thunderstorms ahead of an upper level trough and associated weak cold front moved through the area on the 23rd, providing relief to the oppressive heat for the remainder of the month.

The combination of high pressure and strong offshore flow resulted in an early season heat wave across the Bay Area from June 9th to the 11th. Multiple daily records were broken across the region and multiple power outages were reported due to the heat. Approximately 26,000 people across the region lost power on Monday followed by an additional 30,000 on Tuesday. Three fatalities were reported during the heat event. One man died as a direct result of heat related illness while two others drowned while attempting to cool down during the heat wave. Hot temperatures and dry grass resulted in a vegetation fire that spread to a residence.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bay Area Rapid Transit reported system wide service delays due to equipment problems as a result of the heat https://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/The-Heat-is-On-Bay-Area-Expected-to-Continue-Seeing-Scorching-Temperatures-511107952.html. Timing was estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm period with high pressure and strong mid Summer insolation resulted in high temperatures topping out in the lower 90s. An accidental heat related death occurred in this environment.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Morristown police department found a three year old boy dead in a vehicle due to the heat during the evening. Temperatures during the afternoon and evening were as high as 90 degrees. The child opened the car door and climbed into the vehicle but was not able to determine how to get out.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure prevailed over California between June 10 and June 12 which resulted in much warmer than normal temperatures across the area during the period. High temperatures generally ranged between 102 and 107 degrees each day across much of the San Joaquin Valley prompting the first Excessive Heat Warning of the season. As a result of the heat, emergency cooling centers were opened each afternoon in several municipalities in the San Joaquin Valley during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 102 and 107 degrees at most locations between June 10 and June 12.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper ridge over the Great Basin brought offshore flow and hot temperatures to Southern California June 9th through 12th. The Coachella Valley and San Diego County deserts were the warmest locations with highs 110-117. In the Inland Empire, highs ranged from 105-110. A few locations in the San Diego inland areas (Ramona, Escondido, Alpine) reached the mid to upper 90s during the 4-day heatwave. Many locations broke daily high temperature records; most notably, El Cajon broke its daily record on June 10th by 10 degrees. In San Diego County, a total of 36 people were treated for heat-related illnesses between June 9th and 12th.||Dense fog was observed at the coast and on higher coastal terrain on June 12th with very low visibilities (less than 1/8 of a mile at times). Fog lifted and visibility improved by 9 AM on the 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Inland Empire locations recorded temperatures ranging from 100 to 110 during this 4-day heatwave. June 9th, Riverside reached 104 which was a record.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Areas near and south of Interstate 90 experienced the first dangerous heat of the year. Afternoon and early evening temperatures from 90 to 95, along with dew point readings from 72 to 77 resulted in maximum heat index values of 100 to 105 degrees.  Some higher heat index readings included 106 degrees at Yankton, 103 degrees 5 miles south southeast of Centerville and Le Mars, 102 degrees at Parkston, White Lake and Sioux City, and 101 degrees at Gregory.  Several roads buckled due to the heat near Sioux City.

A strong upper ridge over the Great Basin brought offshore flow and hot temperatures to Southern California June 9th through 12th. The Coachella Valley and San Diego County deserts were the warmest locations with highs 110-117. In the Inland Empire, highs ranged from 105-110. A few locations in the San Diego inland areas (Ramona, Escondido, Alpine) reached the mid to upper 90s during the 4-day heatwave. Many locations broke daily high temperature records; most notably, El Cajon broke its daily record on June 10th by 10 degrees. In San Diego County, a total of 36 people were treated for heat-related illnesses between June 9th and 12th.||Dense fog was observed at the coast and on higher coastal terrain on June 12th with very low visibilities (less than 1/8 of a mile at times). Fog lifted and visibility improved by 9 AM on the 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Palm Springs ASOS reported high temperatures of 107-118 throughout the 4-day heatwave. The warmest day was June 12th when Thermal reached 118 (record) and Palm Springs recorded a high of 116 (1 shy of record). On June 9th and 10th Thermal broke records with a high of 113 and 116. On July 11, Palm Springs tied a record high of 114.

Numerous roads across the region buckled from the heat.||Some of the more extreme heat index readings experienced during the afternoon included 113 degrees at Wagner, 112 degrees at Le Mars, Canton and Mitchell, 111 degrees at Cherokee, Sioux City, Huron and Yankton, and 110 degrees at Sioux Falls, Colton and White Lake.
An extended heat wave came to an end when heat index values reached as high as 110 to 115 degrees on July 21.

Areas near and south of Interstate 90 experienced the first dangerous heat of the year. Afternoon and early evening temperatures from 90 to 95, along with dew point readings from 72 to 77 resulted in maximum heat index values of 100 to 105 degrees.  Some higher heat index readings included 106 degrees at Yankton, 103 degrees 5 miles south southeast of Centerville and Le Mars, 102 degrees at Parkston, White Lake and Sioux City, and 101 degrees at Gregory.  Several roads buckled due to the heat near Sioux City.

Southeast Minnesota sweltered for one day with excessive heat in the middle of July. Heat indices topped out between 105 and 115 on July 19th. Air temperatures during this heat wave generally topped out around 90 while dew points climbed into the lower 80s. The highest calculated heat index was 117 from a mesonet station in Houston (Houston County), near Kellogg (Wabasha County) and the automated weather observing equipment at the Winona airport (Winona County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices of 105 to 115 were common across Fillmore County on July 19th. The highest calculated heat index was 114 from a mesonet station near Canton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Western Wisconsin sweltered under two days of excessive heat in the middle of July. Heat indices topped out between 100 and 110 on July 18th and 105 and 120 on July 19th. Air temperatures during this heat wave generally topped out around 90 while dew points climbed into the lower 80s. The highest calculated heat index was 118 from a mesonet station near Cataract (Monroe County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices of 100 to 115 were common across Vernon County on July 19th. The highest calculated heat index was 115 from the automated weather observing equipment at the Viroqua airport.

A strong upper ridge over the Great Basin brought offshore flow and hot temperatures to Southern California June 9th through 12th. The Coachella Valley and San Diego County deserts were the warmest locations with highs 110-117. In the Inland Empire, highs ranged from 105-110. A few locations in the San Diego inland areas (Ramona, Escondido, Alpine) reached the mid to upper 90s during the 4-day heatwave. Many locations broke daily high temperature records; most notably, El Cajon broke its daily record on June 10th by 10 degrees. In San Diego County, a total of 36 people were treated for heat-related illnesses between June 9th and 12th.||Dense fog was observed at the coast and on higher coastal terrain on June 12th with very low visibilities (less than 1/8 of a mile at times). Fog lifted and visibility improved by 9 AM on the 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The San Diego County deserts observed high temperatures ranging from 105-115 during the 4-day heatwave. Campo and Borrego Springs broke their daily high temperature records on multiple days.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper level high pressure prevailed across the Mid-South. Heat and humidity combined to create dangerous conditions with heat index values of 105 degrees or greater across the Delta region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values exceeded 105 degrees.

With a combination of high temperatures in the 90s and added humidity, heat index values across the region reached into the triple digits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures in the 90s and dewpoints in the upper 70s to near 80 degrees created heat index values in excess of 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Relatively strong high pressure aloft developed across the central deserts of Arizona on June 16th, resulting in high temperatures that were a few degrees above normal. Although the heat was still well below heat warning thresholds, it was still significant enough to result in injuries due to careless behavior. During the early afternoon hours, an infant suffered heat related injuries after being left in a car for an extended period of time. The injury occurred in the greater Phoenix area, about 1 mile west of the town of Goodyear. The high temperature for the day in Phoenix was 107 degrees, just 3 degrees above the normal of 104.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Relatively strong high pressure aloft developed across the central deserts on June 16th allowing high temperatures to climb a few degrees above seasonal normals. Although the heat did not reach to excessive heat warning levels, it was significant enough to result in an injury to an infant left unattended in an automobile. According to local broadcast media, at about 1400MST a five month old baby was found alone in a car; the infant suffered heat-related injuries but was found alive. The baby was found about 1 mile to the west of the town of Goodyear. The high temperature in Phoenix that day was 107 degrees and it was estimated to be about 106 at the time the infant was located.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure shifted east into the Ark-La-Tex on June 21st, and persisted through the 22nd, resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid 90s area-wide each day. When combined with the high humidity due to little mixing of dewpoints, afternoon heat indices ranged between 105-110 degrees each day across McCurtain County Oklahoma. Little relief was found at night, with temperatures only briefly falling into the mid and upper 70s. Cooler temperatures due to a complex of  showers and thunderstorms ahead of an upper level trough and associated weak cold front moved through the area on the 23rd, providing relief to the oppressive heat for the remainder of the month.

Southeast Minnesota sweltered for one day with excessive heat in the middle of July. Heat indices topped out between 105 and 115 on July 19th. Air temperatures during this heat wave generally topped out around 90 while dew points climbed into the lower 80s. The highest calculated heat index was 117 from a mesonet station in Houston (Houston County), near Kellogg (Wabasha County) and the automated weather observing equipment at the Winona airport (Winona County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices of 105 to 115 were common across Houston County on July 19th. The highest calculated heat index was 117 from a mesonet station in Houston.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first Heat Advisory of the summer was issued for the Wednesday through Friday (June 19-21) time frame for a good portion of North and Central Texas. Seasonably hot conditions continued into the weekend. Unfortunately 2 heat-related fatalities occurred, both young children.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices between 105 and 110 degrees occurred across Anderson County during the afternoons of June 19 through June 21, 2019.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure building over the Desert Southwest brought a heat wave to the Bay Area in mid August. Multiple daily high temperature records were broken across the region. Heat prompted the delay of the school year for some students. Additionally, the heat caused a large power outage in the East Bay leaving thousands of residents without power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat caused multiple power outages across portions of the East Bay leaving thousands of residents without power https://www.kron4.com/news/bay-area/extreme-heat-causes-major-power-outage-in-danville/.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure building over the Desert Southwest brought a heat wave to the Bay Area in mid August. Multiple daily high temperature records were broken across the region. Heat prompted the delay of the school year for some students. Additionally, the heat caused a large power outage in the East Bay leaving thousands of residents without power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The start of the school year for some in Pittsburg was delayed due to the heat https://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2019/08/15/heat-wave-liberty-high-brentwood-early-practice-pittsburg-highlands-elementary-postponed/.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure over the south central United States resulted in a period of unseasonably hot weather over eastern Oklahoma from the 17th through the 20th. Afternoon temperatures climbed into the upper 90s each day. These temperatures combined with high humidity resulted in heat index values from 110 to 115 degrees. At least 35 people were treated for heat-related illness in Tulsa on those dates.

An upper level ridge of high pressure over the south central United States resulted in a period of unseasonably hot weather over eastern Oklahoma from the 17th through the 20th. Afternoon temperatures climbed into the upper 90s each day. These temperatures combined with high humidity resulted in heat index values from 110 to 115 degrees. At least 35 people were treated for heat-related illness in Tulsa on those dates.

The first Heat Advisory of the summer was issued for the Wednesday through Friday (June 19-21) time frame for a good portion of North and Central Texas. Seasonably hot conditions continued into the weekend. Unfortunately 2 heat-related fatalities occurred, both young children.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices between 105 and 110 degrees occurred across Collin County during the afternoons of June 20 through June 21, 2019.

An upper level ridge of high pressure that extended from the Texas Hill Country east across Southeast Texas and South Louisiana in wake of the remnants of Hurricane/Tropical Storm Barry, shifted north across the Ark-La-Tex on July 17th. Compressional warming beneath this ridge of high pressure resulted in temperatures climbing into the middle 90s across North Louisiana. Only minimal mixing of the dewpoints was observed, and when combined with the humidity, heat indices ranged from 105-107 degrees. Despite the upper ridge lingering over the area for the next several days afterwards, slightly better mixing kept maximum heat indices below 105 degrees despite temperatures climbing into the middle 90s across North Louisiana.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure over the south central United States resulted in unseasonably hot weather over west central Arkansas on the 17th. Afternoon temperatures climbed into the upper 90s. These temperatures combined with high humidity resulted in heat index values from 105 to 115 degrees.

A large upper level ridge of high pressure was anchored over Southcentral Texas into the Lower Mississippi and Tennessee Vallies July 9th and 10th, resulting in an expansive area of sinking air which allowed for afternoon temperatures to climb into the mid 90s each day. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during this time, with the resultant heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across East Texas. A weak cool front and associated upper level shortwave trough moved through the area during the morning and afternoon hours on the 11th, but the slightly cooler air and lower humidities were not able to mix south through the region until the evening hours through the morning on the 12th. Thus, afternoon temperatures on July 11th again rose into the mid 90s, with the resultant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees.

An upper level ridge of high pressure that extended from the Texas Hill Country east across Southeast Texas and South Louisiana in wake of the remnants of Hurricane/Tropical Storm Barry, shifted north across the Ark-La-Tex on July 17th. Compressional warming beneath this ridge of high pressure resulted in temperatures climbing into the middle 90s across East Texas. Only minimal mixing of the dewpoints was observed, and when combined with the humidity, heat indices rose to near 105 degrees. Despite the upper ridge lingering over the area for the next several days afterwards, slightly better mixing kept maximum heat indices below 105 degrees despite temperatures climbing into the middle 90s across East Texas.

Heat index values reached 105-107 degrees in northwest Alabama during the early to mid afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index reached around 106 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures climbed into the middle 90s with dew points in the lower 70s. This produced heat index values around 105 degrees during the mid afternoon hours in northwest Alabama.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index reached 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105-107 degrees in northwest Alabama during the early to mid afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index reached around 106 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level ridge of high pressure was anchored over Southcentral Texas into the Lower Mississippi and Tennessee Vallies July 9th and 10th, resulting in an expansive area of sinking air which allowed for afternoon temperatures to climb into the mid 90s each day. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during this time, with the resultant heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across East Texas. A weak cool front and associated upper level shortwave trough moved through the area during the morning and afternoon hours on the 11th, but the slightly cooler air and lower humidities were not able to mix south through the region until the evening hours through the morning on the 12th. Thus, afternoon temperatures on July 11th again rose into the mid 90s, with the resultant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees.

The first Heat Advisory of the summer was issued for the Wednesday through Friday (June 19-21) time frame for a good portion of North and Central Texas. Seasonably hot conditions continued into the weekend. Unfortunately 2 heat-related fatalities occurred, both young children.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices between 105 and 110 degrees occurred across Limestone County during the afternoons of June 19 through June 21, 2019.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level ridge of high pressure was anchored over Southcentral Texas into the Lower Mississippi and Tennessee Vallies July 9th and 10th, resulting in an expansive area of sinking air which allowed for afternoon temperatures to climb into the mid 90s each day. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during this time, with the resultant heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across Northeast Texas. A weak cool front and associated upper level shortwave trough moved through the area during the evening of the 10th through the overnight hours into the 11th, allowing for scattered showers and thunderstorms to develop and move through the region. Slightly cooler temperatures and lower humidities were observed in wake of the frontal passage across Northeast Texas on July 11th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After the remnants of hurricane Barry departed to the northeast of Arkansas on the 17th, high pressure and hot weather returned for several days.  An ex NFL football player died of heat stroke on July 18, 2019.  This was a result of the hot and humid conditions at this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An ex NFL football player suffered from heat stroke in Carlisle, AR while working outside at his parent's shop.  He later died at a hospital in North Little Rock, AR. He was 32 years old.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure aloft forced a thermal trough near the coast to move inland, bringing hot and dry conditions to the inland west side valleys in southwest Oregon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The only reported high temperature in this zone on 08/27 was 105 degrees at the Illinois Valley RAWS.  Reported highs ranged from 84 to 98 degrees on 08/28.  Low temperatures on the morning of 08/28 ranged from 57 to 72 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure aloft forced a thermal trough near the coast to move inland, bringing hot and dry conditions to the inland west side valleys in northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two stations reported high temperatures of 107 degrees on 08/27 and the highs ranged from 91 to 98 degrees on 08/28.  Low temperatures on the morning of 08/28 ranged from 48 to 60 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure aloft forced a thermal trough near the coast to move inland, bringing hot and dry conditions to the inland west side valleys in northern California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported high temperatures in this zone ranged from 102 to 104 degrees on 08/27 and from 92 to 96 degrees on 08/28.  Low temperatures on the morning of 08/28 ranged from 61 to 64 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure over the south central United States resulted in a period of unseasonably hot weather over eastern Oklahoma from the 17th through the 20th. Afternoon temperatures climbed into the upper 90s each day. These temperatures combined with high humidity resulted in heat index values from 110 to 115 degrees. At least 35 people were treated for heat-related illness in Tulsa on those dates.

Afternoon temperatures climbed into the upper 90s each day. These temperatures combined with high humidity resulted in heat index values from 110 to 115 degrees. At least 35 people were treated for heat-related illness in Tulsa on those dates.

A large upper level ridge of high pressure was anchored over Southcentral Texas into the Lower Mississippi and Tennessee Vallies July 9th and 10th, resulting in an expansive area of sinking air which allowed for afternoon temperatures to climb into the mid 90s each day. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during this time, with the resultant heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across McCurtain County Oklahoma. A weak cool front and associated upper level shortwave trough moved through the area during the evening of the 10th, allowing for scattered showers and thunderstorms to develop and move through the region, with slightly cooler temperatures and lower humidities observed in wake of the frontal passage across Southeast Oklahoma on July 11th.

A large upper level ridge of high pressure was anchored over Southcentral Texas into the Lower Mississippi and Tennessee Vallies July 9th and 10th, resulting in an expansive area of sinking air which allowed for afternoon temperatures to climb into the mid 90s each day. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during this time, with the resultant heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across Southwest Arkansas. A weak cool front and associated upper level shortwave trough moved through the area during the evening of the 10th, allowing for scattered showers and thunderstorms to develop and move through the region, with slightly cooler temperatures and lower humidities observed in wake of the frontal passage across Southwest Arkansas on July 11th.

A large upper level ridge of high pressure was anchored over Southcentral Texas into the Lower Mississippi and Tennessee Vallies July 9th and 10th, resulting in an expansive area of sinking air which allowed for afternoon temperatures to climb into the mid 90s each day. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during this time, with the resultant heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across Southcentral Arkansas. A weak cool front and associated upper level shortwave trough moved through the area during the morning and afternoon of the 11th, but the slightly cooler and drier air were delayed in mixing across the area until the evening and overnight hours into July 12th. Thus, afternoon temperatures again warmed into the mid 90s across Southcentral Arkansas, with resultant heat indices ranging from 105 to 108 degrees.

A large upper level ridge of high pressure was anchored over Southcentral Texas into the Lower Mississippi and Tennessee Vallies July 9th and 10th, resulting in an expansive area of sinking air which allowed for afternoon temperatures to climb into the mid 90s each day. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during this time, with the resultant heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across Northeast Texas. A weak cool front and associated upper level shortwave trough moved through the area during the evening of the 10th through the overnight hours into the 11th, allowing for scattered showers and thunderstorms to develop and move through the region. Slightly cooler temperatures and lower humidities were observed in wake of the frontal passage across Northeast Texas on July 11th.

The first Heat Advisory of the summer was issued for the Wednesday through Friday (June 19-21) time frame for a good portion of North and Central Texas. Seasonably hot conditions continued into the weekend. Unfortunately 2 heat-related fatalities occurred, both young children.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices between 105 and 110 degrees occurred across Jack County during the afternoons of June 19 through June 20, 2019.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first two weeks of August, while eventually expanding east into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana, resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees each day. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area south of a weak stationary front over Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas, which only allowed for minimal mixing each afternoon. This resulted in heat indices consistently ranging from 105-110 degrees each day across East Texas from the afternoon of the 7th to the 14th. A weak surface front moved through the area during the afternoon of the 14th, bringing about isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms and eventually, lower humidity by the 15th, providing brief relief from the heat.

An upper level ridge of high pressure in place across the Southern Plains during the first week of August expanded east into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana during the second week of the month, resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area where low level moisture continued to pool from Southeast Oklahoma and much of Southwest Arkansas near a weak stationary front, and did not allow for much mixing. This resulted in heat indices consistently ranging from 110-114 degrees across much of Southeast Oklahoma including McCurtain County from the afternoon of the 11th through the 13th. A weak surface front moved through the area on the 14th, bringing about isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms and eventually, lower humidity, providing brief relief from the heat.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Building high pressure and offshore flow caused a rapid warm-up across the Bay Area prompting two days worth of heat advisories along with several daily record high temperatures. Stronger offshore flow compared to a mid-September heat wave also created increased fire danger and the issuance of a Red Flag Warning. Heat related power failure in the North Bay left several thousand customers without power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat related power failure in northwest Santa Rosa on Wednesday September 25th left 5,500 customers without power https://www.pressdemocrat.com/news/10096356-181/power-cut-off-to-5500?sba=AAS.

Upper level high pressure over the Great Basin ushered in gusty Santa Ana winds, hot temperatures and single digit relative humidity. Many SoCal locations took the nation's high temperature between October 21-24. Although it was hot and dry October 21-22, winds were not very strong. The stronger winds occurred on October 24-25, where widespread wind gusts of 50-60 mph winds occurred in the mountains and passes, with isolated gusts of 70+ mph. The highest wind gust was 78 mph at Sill Hill in San Diego County. Five small fires started between October 24-25. The Miller Fire in Valley Center burned 70 acres in heavy vegetation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures resulted from Santa Ana winds on October 21st in inland Orange County. Anaheim reached 98, Fullerton reached 96 and Yorba Linda reached 97.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures resulted from Santa Ana winds on October 21st in the San Diego County valleys. Santee reached 96, El Cajon reached 93 and Ramona reached 94.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over Southern California brought hot temperatures to the inland areas. 850 millibar temperatures ranged from 28-30 degrees Celsius over the eastern portion of the region. High temperatures in the Coachella Valley ranged from 113-118, where Palm Springs reached 118 degrees. The Inland Empire experienced hot weather too, with high temperatures ranging from 97-111 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures in the Coachella Valley ranged from 113-118 degrees both July 27th and 28th, with the highest temperature of 118 at Palm Springs Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure centered near the Four Corners brought deadly heat and excessive heat warning conditions to the region. Eleven fatalities (9 direct and 2 indirect) were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One direct fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender and circumstances unavailable.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Maximum heat index values of 105 to 110 degrees Fahrenheit. An increase in emergency room visits for heat exhaustion occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were recorded in southeast Arizona on July 15th and 16th. No heat-related fatalities were reported despite a record-tying high temperature of 110 degrees at Tucson International Airport on the 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures occurred on July 15th and 16th with respective high temperatures of 110 and 111 degrees at Organ Pipe National Monument, 109 and 108 at Sells, 108 and 110 (tied record) at Tucson International Airport, and 109 both days at the Safford Airport.

CZ_NAME: UPPER GILA RIVER AND ARAVAIPA VALLEYS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were recorded in southeast Arizona on July 15th and 16th. No heat-related fatalities were reported despite a record-tying high temperature of 110 degrees at Tucson International Airport on the 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures occurred on July 15th and 16th with respective high temperatures of 110 and 111 degrees at Organ Pipe National Monument, 109 and 108 at Sells, 108 and 110 (tied record) at Tucson International Airport, and 109 both days at the Safford Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced in parts of southeast Arizona on July 10th, 11th and 12th with record high temperatures tied or set in some locations. Four heat-related fatalities occurred--one in western Pima County and three on the Tohono O'odham Nation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Well above normal temperatures occurred in southeast Arizona July 10th through the 12th.  Record high temperatures include 110 degrees (tie) at Tucson International Airport and 107 degrees at Sasabe on the 10th, 110 degrees at Sells and Safford (tie), 108 at Sasabe, 107 at Willcox, 106 at Duncan (tie) and 104 at Nogales Airport on the 11th, and 111 degrees (tie) at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument and 108 at Sasabe on the 12th.   The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three adult males and one unidentified male during this time frame but exact dates are estimated.  One individual perished on the grounds of Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument on the 10th.  Three others died on the Tohono O'odham Nation--one in the vicinity of Menager's Dam on the 10th, another near Papago Farms on the 11th, and a third near San Miguel on the 12th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat indices peaked between 105 and 110 degrees during the afternoon hours. A combination of temperatures in the mid 90's and dew points in the mid 70's produced these hazardous heat indices. A southwest wind flow of hot and humid air ahead of a cold front was responsible for this first potentially dangerous heat event of the season.

A very large high in the upper levels of the atmosphere was sprawled across the southern two-thirds of the country for several days. This high brought three to four days of oppressive heat and humidity across southern Illinois. Cooling centers were opened at various public offices, including Carbondale city hall and health offices in Union and Williamson Counties. Afternoon heat indices peaked between 101 and 111 degrees each day from the 18th to the 21st. The heat index at Carbondale peaked at 111 degrees on the 18th, and 107 to 108 from the 19th to the 21st. Heat indices in the southeast counties were not quite as high, but still around 105 each day. Just prior to this heat wave, the remnants of Tropical Storm Barry produced a widespread soaking rain that set the stage for very high humidity levels. Dew points were in the mid 70's. Actual high temperatures were in the lower 90's.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first two weeks of August, while eventually expanding east into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana, resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid to upper 90s each day. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area south of a weak stationary front over Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas, which only allowed for minimal mixing each afternoon. This resulted in heat indices consistently ranging from 105-110 degrees each day across North Louisiana from the afternoon of the 7th to the 11th. However, as the upper ridge moved into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana during the second week of August, afternoon temperatures climbed into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees by the afternoon of the 11th, and when combined with the high humidity, resulted in a period of excessive heat over the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure strengthened over the four corners region on July 24 and 25 and resulted in widespread triple digit heat across the San Joaquin Valley. The high then built westward into central California between July 26 and 28. This resulted in a continued warming trend across the area between July 26 and July 28. The 28th which was the warmest day before the high broke down and gave way to a cooling trend which ended the widespread triple digit heat by July 30.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 102 and 107 degrees at most locations between July 25 and July 29.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large ridge of high pressure building over the Midwest brought a period of hot and humid weather to central Illinois from July 17th through July 21st.  High temperatures routinely topped out in the lower to middle 90s during that time frame, while overnight lows only cooled into the middle to upper 70s.  High relative humidity values helped push maximum afternoon heat index values to 105 degrees or higher.  A cold front eventually brought relief to areas along and west of I-55 by July 21st...with cooler conditions not arriving further east until the 22nd.  Due to the prolonged period of excessive heat and humidity, two people died across central Illinois.  An 81-year old man in Flora in Clay County passed away on July 18th, while a 61-year old woman died in Peoria on July 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 61-year old woman died from heatstroke in Peoria on July 21st.  She was found inside a 97-degree house with no air conditioning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The beginning of a prolonged heat wave brought heat index values of 105 to 115 degree for much of Eastern North Carolina during the middle part of July. July 13 was particularly hot and humid with some area heat indices reaching 110 to 115 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 1155 LST and 1415 LST the temperature at KOCW was between 93 and 95 degrees with a dew point of 74 or greater.  These values combined to produce a heat index of 106 or greater during this time on July 13th, 2019. ||The peak heat index occurred at 1255 LST with a temperature of 94 and a dewpoint of 76 producing a heat index of 107 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The beginning of a prolonged heat wave brought heat index values of 105 to 115 degree for much of Eastern North Carolina during the middle part of July. July 13 was particularly hot and humid with some area heat indices reaching 110 to 115 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The temperature at KOAJ was 93 with a dew point of 79 which produced a heat index of 110 at the following times on July 13th, 2019:||1030 - 1100 LST, 1100 - 1145 LST, 1155 - 1205 LST, 1215- 1246 LST.||The peak heat index occurred at 1200 LST with a temperature of 95 and a dewpoint of 79 producing a heat index of 113 degrees.

A very large high in the upper levels of the atmosphere was sprawled across the southern two-thirds of the country for several days. This high brought several days of oppressive heat and humidity across western Kentucky. The Salvation Army in Hopkinsville opened a cooling center for anybody needing relief from the dangerous heat indices. Afternoon heat indices peaked between 100 and 109 degrees each day from the 17th to the 21st. The heat index at Paducah peaked at 102 degrees on the 17th, 106 on the 18th, and 103 to 106 from the 19th to the 21st. At Madisonville, the heat index peaked from 103 to 106 each of those five afternoons. Just prior to this heat wave, the remnants of Tropical Storm Barry produced a widespread soaking rain that set the stage for very high humidity levels. Dew points were in the mid to upper 70's. Actual high temperatures were mainly in the lower 90's.

A large area of high pressure strengthened over the four corners region on July 24 and 25 and resulted in widespread triple digit heat across the San Joaquin Valley. The high then built westward into central California between July 26 and 28. This resulted in a continued warming trend across the area between July 26 and July 28. The 28th which was the warmest day before the high broke down and gave way to a cooling trend which ended the widespread triple digit heat by July 30.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 102 and 107 degrees at most locations between July 25 and July 29.

This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area south of a weak stationary front over Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas, which only allowed for minimal mixing each afternoon. This resulted in heat indices consistently ranging from 105-110 degrees each day across East Texas from the afternoon of the 7th to the 14th. A weak surface front moved through the area during the afternoon of the 14th, bringing about isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms and eventually, lower humidity by the 15th, providing brief relief from the heat.

The beginning of a prolonged heat wave brought heat index values of 105 to 115 degree for much of Eastern North Carolina during the middle part of July. July 13 was particularly hot and humid with some area heat indices reaching 110 to 115 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The temperature at KEWN was 91 with a dew point of 81 which produced a heat index of 111 at the following times on July 13th, 2019:||11:30 - 11:40 LST||The temperature at KEWN was at least 93 or higher, with a dewpoint of 79 or higher between 12:20 LST and 13:30 LST producing a heat index of at least 110 degrees or higher. ||The peak heat index occurred at 1320 LST with a temperature of 95 and a dewpoint of 79 producing a heat index of 113 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure that extended from the Texas Hill Country east across Southeast Texas and South Louisiana in wake of the remnants of Hurricane/Tropical Storm Barry, shifted north across the Ark-La-Tex on July 17th. Compressional warming beneath this ridge of high pressure resulted in temperatures climbing into the lower and middle 90s across Southwest Arkansas. Only minimal mixing of the dewpoints was observed, and when combined with the humidity, heat indices ranged from 105-106 degrees. Despite the upper ridge lingering over the area for the next several days afterwards, slightly better mixing kept maximum heat indices below 105 degrees despite temperatures climbing into the lower and middle 90s across Southwest Arkansas.

A very large high in the upper levels of the atmosphere was sprawled across the southern two-thirds of the country for several days. This high brought several days of oppressive heat and humidity across western Kentucky. The Salvation Army in Hopkinsville opened a cooling center for anybody needing relief from the dangerous heat indices. Afternoon heat indices peaked between 100 and 109 degrees each day from the 17th to the 21st. The heat index at Paducah peaked at 102 degrees on the 17th, 106 on the 18th, and 103 to 106 from the 19th to the 21st. At Madisonville, the heat index peaked from 103 to 106 each of those five afternoons. Just prior to this heat wave, the remnants of Tropical Storm Barry produced a widespread soaking rain that set the stage for very high humidity levels. Dew points were in the mid to upper 70's. Actual high temperatures were mainly in the lower 90's.

A large area of high pressure strengthened over the four corners region on July 24 and 25 and resulted in widespread triple digit heat across the San Joaquin Valley. The high then built westward into central California between July 26 and 28. This resulted in a continued warming trend across the area between July 26 and July 28. The 28th which was the warmest day before the high broke down and gave way to a cooling trend which ended the widespread triple digit heat by July 30.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 102 and 107 degrees at most locations between July 25 and July 29.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Northeast Iowa sweltered under two days of excessive heat in the middle of July.  Heat indices topped out between 100 and 110 on July 18th and between 105 and 120 on July 19th.  Air temperatures during this heat wave generally topped out around 90 while dew points climbed into the lower 80s. The highest calculated heat index was 117 from a mesonet station near McGregor (Clayton County) and the automated weather observing equipment at the Oelwein airport (Fayette County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices of 100 to 105 were common across Allamakee County on July 18 and 19th. The highest calculated heat index was 105 from a mesonet station near Waterville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first two weeks of August, while eventually expanding east into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana, resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid to upper 90s each day. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area south of a weak stationary front over Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas, which only allowed for minimal mixing each afternoon. A heat wave gripped western Massachusetts from July 19th through the 21st. Temperatures soared to the low 90s with dewpoints in the low to mid-70s. This resulted in heat index values in the 95 to 105 range in the warmest valleys. Saturday, July 20th was the hottest day for most areas. Due to the excessive heat, cooling centers were opened and pool hours were extended.||The hot and humid airmass provided fuel for thunderstorms that formed along the Lake Ontario shoreline during the late afternoon of the 20th. One storm advanced into Berkshire County in the evening, resulting in a report of wind damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures in the 90s along with high dewpoints in the 70s resulted in heat index values between 100 and 105 on the afternoon of July 11. A 3-year old boy left unattended in a hot car died from heat stroke in Rutherford County. Elsewhere, isolated showers and thunderstorms developed across the southeastern half of Middle Tennessee during the evening hours on July 11. One report of minor wind damage was received in Putnam County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 3 year old boy left unattended in a hot car for around 2 hours died from heat stroke in Smyrna. The nearby Smyrna Airport AWOS reported a temperature of 91, dewpoint of 74, and heat index of 101 at 5pm CDT.

An upper level ridge of high pressure that extended from the Texas Hill Country east across Southeast Texas and South Louisiana in wake of the remnants of Hurricane/Tropical Storm Barry, shifted north across the Ark-La-Tex on July 17th. Compressional warming beneath this ridge of high pressure resulted in temperatures climbing into the middle 90s across Southeast Oklahoma. Only minimal mixing of the dewpoints was observed, and when combined with the humidity, heat indices rose to near 105 degrees. Despite the upper ridge lingering over the area for the next several days afterwards, slightly better mixing kept maximum heat indices below 105 degrees despite temperatures climbing into the middle 90s.

An upper level ridge of high pressure that extended from the Texas Hill Country east across Southeast Texas and South Louisiana in wake of the remnants of Hurricane/Tropical Storm Barry, shifted north across the Ark-La-Tex on July 17th. Compressional warming beneath this ridge of high pressure resulted in temperatures climbing into the lower and middle 90s across Southwest Arkansas. Only minimal mixing of the dewpoints was observed, and when combined with the humidity, heat indices ranged from 105-106 degrees. Despite the upper ridge lingering over the area for the next several days afterwards, slightly better mixing kept maximum heat indices below 105 degrees despite temperatures climbing into the lower and middle 90s across Southwest Arkansas.

An upper level ridge of high pressure that extended from the Texas Hill Country east across Southeast Texas and South Louisiana in wake of the remnants of Hurricane/Tropical Storm Barry, shifted north across the Ark-La-Tex on July 17th. Despite the upper ridge lingering over the area for the next several days afterwards, slightly better mixing kept maximum heat indices below 105 degrees despite temperatures climbing into the lower and middle 90s across Southwest Arkansas.

A very large high in the upper levels of the atmosphere was sprawled across the southern two-thirds of the country for several days. This high brought several days of oppressive heat and humidity across western Kentucky. The Salvation Army in Hopkinsville opened a cooling center for anybody needing relief from the dangerous heat indices. Afternoon heat indices peaked between 100 and 109 degrees each day from the 17th to the 21st. The heat index at Paducah peaked at 102 degrees on the 17th, 106 on the 18th, and 103 to 106 from the 19th to the 21st. At Madisonville, the heat index peaked from 103 to 106 each of those five afternoons. Just prior to this heat wave, the remnants of Tropical Storm Barry produced a widespread soaking rain that set the stage for very high humidity levels. Dew points were in the mid to upper 70's. Actual high temperatures were mainly in the lower 90's.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions spread into northern Illinois during the late afternoon and early evening of July 18th and persisted through the late afternoon of July 20th when a cold front moved south across northern Illinois.  High temperatures reached the lower to middle 90s on July 19th and in the middle 90s on July 20th.  Peak afternoon heat indices were between 110 to 115 both days.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first two weeks of August, while eventually expanding east into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana, resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees each day. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area south of a weak stationary front over Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas, which only allowed for minimal mixing each afternoon. This resulted in heat indices consistently ranging from 105-110 degrees each day across East Texas from the afternoon of the 7th to the 14th. A weak surface front moved through the area during the afternoon of the 14th, bringing about isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms and eventually, lower humidity by the 15th, providing brief relief from the heat.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over Southern California brought heat to the inland areas. High temperatures in the Inland Empire ranged from 100 to 110 before cooling down slightly on July 25th. High temperatures in the San Diego County valleys ranged from 95-101 degrees, and highs in the Orange County Inland areas ranged from 95-100 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures in the Inland Empire ranged from 100 to 108 degrees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures in the San Diego County valleys ranged from 95-101 degrees, especially in the eastern portion of the valleys.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very large high in the upper levels of the atmosphere was sprawled across the southern two-thirds of the country for several days. This high brought several days of oppressive heat and humidity across southeast Missouri. An outdoor marketplace in Cape Girardeau closed early due to the heat. Afternoon heat indices peaked between 105 and 115 degrees each day from the 17th to the 21st. The heat index at Poplar Bluff peaked at 115 degrees on the 17th, 113 on the 18th, and 108 to 109 from the 19th to the 21st. At Cape Girardeau, the heat index peaked from 105 to 109 each of those five afternoons. Just prior to this heat wave, the remnants of Tropical Storm Barry produced a widespread soaking rain that set the stage for very high humidity levels. Dew points were sometimes in the upper 70's. Actual high temperatures were in the lower 90's.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level ridge of high pressure was anchored over Southcentral Texas into the Lower Mississippi and Tennessee Vallies July 9th and 10th, resulting in an expansive area of sinking air which allowed for afternoon temperatures to climb into the mid 90s each day. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during this time, with the resultant heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across North Louisiana. A weak cool front and associated upper level shortwave trough moved through the area during the afternoon hours on the 11th, but the slightly cooler air and lower humidities were not able to mix south through the region until the evening hours through the morning on the 12th. Thus, afternoon temperatures across North Louisiana on July 11th again rose into the mid 90s, with the resultant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Desert Southwest remained under the influence of high pressure during the early part of August and led to above normal temperatures on the 7th and 8th. Five heat-associated fatalities (1 direct and 4 indirect) were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One indirect fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender and circumstances unavailable.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first two weeks of August, while eventually expanding east into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana, resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid to upper 90s each day. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area south of a weak stationary front over Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas, which only allowed for minimal mixing each afternoon. This resulted in heat indices consistently ranging from 105-110 degrees each day across North Louisiana from the afternoon of the 7th to the 11th. However, as the upper ridge moved into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana during the second week of August, afternoon temperatures climbed into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees by the afternoon of the 11th, and when combined with the high humidity, resulted in a period of excessive heat over the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first two weeks of August, while eventually expanding east into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana, resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees each day. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area south of a weak stationary front over Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas, which only allowed for minimal mixing each afternoon. This resulted in heat indices consistently ranging from 105-110 degrees each day across East Texas from the afternoon of the 7th to the 14th. A weak surface front moved through the area during the afternoon of the 14th, bringing about isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms and eventually, lower humidity by the 15th, providing brief relief from the heat.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first two weeks of August, while eventually expanding east into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana, resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid to upper 90s each day. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area south of a weak stationary front over Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas, which only allowed for minimal mixing each afternoon. This resulted in heat indices consistently ranging from 105-110 degrees each day across North Louisiana from the afternoon of the 7th to the 11th. However, as the upper ridge moved into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana during the second week of August, afternoon temperatures climbed into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees by the afternoon of the 11th, and when combined with the high humidity, resulted in a period of excessive heat over the region.

Strong high pressure centered near the Four Corners brought deadly heat and excessive heat warning conditions to the region. Eleven fatalities (9 direct and 2 indirect) were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One direct fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender and circumstances unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very large high in the upper levels of the atmosphere was sprawled across the southern two-thirds of the country for several days. This high brought several days of oppressive heat and humidity across southeast Missouri. An outdoor marketplace in Cape Girardeau closed early due to the heat. Afternoon heat indices peaked between 105 and 115 degrees each day from the 17th to the 21st. The heat index at Poplar Bluff peaked at 115 degrees on the 17th, 113 on the 18th, and 108 to 109 from the 19th to the 21st. At Cape Girardeau, the heat index peaked from 105 to 109 each of those five afternoons. Just prior to this heat wave, the remnants of Tropical Storm Barry produced a widespread soaking rain that set the stage for very high humidity levels. Dew points were sometimes in the upper 70's. Actual high temperatures were in the lower 90's.

A very large high in the upper levels of the atmosphere was sprawled across the southern two-thirds of the country for several days. This high brought several days of oppressive heat and humidity across western Kentucky. The Salvation Army in Hopkinsville opened a cooling center for anybody needing relief from the dangerous heat indices. Afternoon heat indices peaked between 100 and 109 degrees each day from the 17th to the 21st. The heat index at Paducah peaked at 102 degrees on the 17th, 106 on the 18th, and 103 to 106 from the 19th to the 21st. At Madisonville, the heat index peaked from 103 to 106 each of those five afternoons. Just prior to this heat wave, the remnants of Tropical Storm Barry produced a widespread soaking rain that set the stage for very high humidity levels. Dew points were in the mid to upper 70's. Actual high temperatures were mainly in the lower 90's.

Unusually hot temperatures occurred across the region during the 20th. Across portions of the Central Highlands and Downeast Maine apparent temperatures reached Heat Advisory levels. The combination of temperatures ranging from the upper 80s to the mid 90s...with dewpoints around 70...produced Heat Index values ranging from the mid 90s to near 100 degrees during the afternoon. A cold front crossed the region during the 21st with lower temperatures and dewpoints in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A combination of temperatures ranging from the upper 80s to mid 90s...with dewpoints around 70...produced Heat Index values ranging from the mid 90s to near 100 degrees during the afternoon.
