EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first two weeks of August, while eventually expanding east into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana, resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees each day. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area south of a weak stationary front over Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas, which only allowed for minimal mixing each afternoon. This resulted in heat indices consistently ranging from 105-110 degrees each day across East Texas from the afternoon of the 7th to the 14th. A weak surface front moved through the area during the afternoon of the 14th, bringing about isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms and eventually, lower humidity by the 15th, providing brief relief from the heat.

A large upper level ridge of high pressure was anchored over Southcentral Texas into the Lower Mississippi and Tennessee Vallies July 9th and 10th, resulting in an expansive area of sinking air which allowed for afternoon temperatures to climb into the mid 90s each day. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during this time, with the resultant heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across North Louisiana. A weak cool front and associated upper level shortwave trough moved through the area during the afternoon hours on the 11th, but the slightly cooler air and lower humidities were not able to mix south through the region until the evening hours through the morning on the 12th. Thus, afternoon temperatures across North Louisiana on July 11th again rose into the mid 90s, with the resultant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Northeast Iowa sweltered under two days of excessive heat in the middle of July.  Heat indices topped out between 100 and 110 on July 18th and between 105 and 120 on July 19th.  Air temperatures during this heat wave generally topped out around 90 while dew points climbed into the lower 80s. The highest calculated heat index was 117 from a mesonet station near McGregor (Clayton County) and the automated weather observing equipment at the Oelwein airport (Fayette County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices of 100 to 115 were common across Floyd County on July 18th and 19th. The highest calculated heat index was 113 from the automated weather observing equipment at the Charles City airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first two weeks of August, while eventually expanding east into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana, resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid to upper 90s each day. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area south of a weak stationary front over Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas, which only allowed for minimal mixing each afternoon. This resulted in heat indices consistently ranging from 105-110 degrees each day across North Louisiana from the afternoon of the 7th to the 11th. However, as the upper ridge moved into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana during the second week of August, afternoon temperatures climbed into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees by the afternoon of the 11th, and when combined with the high humidity, resulted in a period of excessive heat over the region.
With a combination of high temperatures in the 90s and added humidity, heat index values across the region reached into the triple digits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures in the 90s and dewpoints in the upper 70s to near 80 degrees created heat index values in excess of 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures led to heat advisories and excessive heat warnings to be issued many days over this period, with numerous reports of people being treated for heat related illnesses as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A total of 87 people were treated for heat related illnesses, mostly over the 4th of July holiday.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure centered near the Four Corners brought deadly heat and excessive heat warning conditions to the region. Eleven fatalities (9 direct and 2 indirect) were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health.

Strong high pressure centered near the Four Corners brought deadly heat and excessive heat warning conditions to the region. Eleven fatalities (9 direct and 2 indirect) were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health.

A very large high in the upper levels of the atmosphere was sprawled across the southern two-thirds of the country for several days. This high brought several days of oppressive heat and humidity across southeast Missouri. An outdoor marketplace in Cape Girardeau closed early due to the heat. Afternoon heat indices peaked between 105 and 115 degrees each day from the 17th to the 21st. The heat index at Poplar Bluff peaked at 115 degrees on the 17th, 113 on the 18th, and 108 to 109 from the 19th to the 21st. At Cape Girardeau, the heat index peaked from 105 to 109 each of those five afternoons. Just prior to this heat wave, the remnants of Tropical Storm Barry produced a widespread soaking rain that set the stage for very high humidity levels. Dew points were sometimes in the upper 70's. Actual high temperatures were in the lower 90's.

A very large high in the upper levels of the atmosphere was sprawled across the southern two-thirds of the country for several days. This high brought several days of oppressive heat and humidity across western Kentucky. The Salvation Army in Hopkinsville opened a cooling center for anybody needing relief from the dangerous heat indices. Afternoon heat indices peaked between 100 and 109 degrees each day from the 17th to the 21st. The heat index at Paducah peaked at 102 degrees on the 17th, 106 on the 18th, and 103 to 106 from the 19th to the 21st. At Madisonville, the heat index peaked from 103 to 106 each of those five afternoons. Just prior to this heat wave, the remnants of Tropical Storm Barry produced a widespread soaking rain that set the stage for very high humidity levels. Dew points were in the mid to upper 70's. Actual high temperatures were mainly in the lower 90's.

Unusually hot temperatures occurred across the region during the 20th. Across portions of the Central Highlands and Downeast Maine apparent temperatures reached Heat Advisory levels. The combination of temperatures ranging from the upper 80s to the mid 90s...with dewpoints around 70...produced Heat Index values ranging from the mid 90s to near 100 degrees during the afternoon. A cold front crossed the region during the 21st with lower temperatures and dewpoints in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A combination of temperatures ranging from the upper 80s to mid 90s...with dewpoints around 70...produced Heat Index values ranging from the mid 90s to near 100 degrees during the afternoon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level ridge of high pressure was anchored over Southcentral Texas into the Lower Mississippi and Tennessee Vallies July 9th and 10th, resulting in an expansive area of sinking air which allowed for afternoon temperatures to climb into the mid 90s each day. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during this time, with the resultant heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across North Louisiana. A weak cool front and associated upper level shortwave trough moved through the area during the afternoon hours on the 11th, but the slightly cooler air and lower humidities were not able to mix south through the region until the evening hours through the morning on the 12th. Thus, afternoon temperatures across North Louisiana on July 11th again rose into the mid 90s, with the resultant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure centered near the Four Corners led to dangerous heat across the Phoenix area. The heat led to 13 fatalities (5 direct and 8 indirect) according to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two fatalities (1 direct and 1 indirect) were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender and circumstances unavailable.

A very large high in the upper levels of the atmosphere was sprawled across the southern two-thirds of the country for several days. This high brought three to four days of oppressive heat and humidity across southern Illinois. Cooling centers were opened at various public offices, including Carbondale city hall and health offices in Union and Williamson Counties. Afternoon heat indices peaked between 101 and 111 degrees each day from the 18th to the 21st. The heat index at Carbondale peaked at 111 degrees on the 18th, and 107 to 108 from the 19th to the 21st. Heat indices in the southeast counties were not quite as high, but still around 105 each day. Just prior to this heat wave, the remnants of Tropical Storm Barry produced a widespread soaking rain that set the stage for very high humidity levels. Dew points were in the mid 70's. Actual high temperatures were in the lower 90's.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southeast Minnesota sweltered for one day with excessive heat in the middle of July. Heat indices topped out between 105 and 115 on July 19th. Air temperatures during this heat wave generally topped out around 90 while dew points climbed into the lower 80s. The highest calculated heat index was 117 from a mesonet station in Houston (Houston County), near Kellogg (Wabasha County) and the automated weather observing equipment at the Winona airport (Winona County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices of 105 to 115 were common across Dodge County on July 19th. The highest calculated heat index was 113 from a mesonet station near Kasson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With high temperatures in the 90s and high relative humidity values, heat index readings hovered near 100 degrees on July 3rd.  As a result of the heat, a 66-year old man died of heatstroke in Paris in Edgar County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 66 year-old man died of heatstroke while sitting in his car outside a home in Paris in Edgar County.  He lived in the non air-conditioned attic of the home, where temperatures likely exceeded 140 degrees on hot days.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure over the Desert Southwest near the end of the month led excessive heat warning conditions for parts of the region. The deadly heat resulted in 25 fatalities (20 direct and 5 indirect) according to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten fatalities (8 direct and 2 indirect) were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender and circumstances unavailable.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One direct fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender and circumstances unavailable.

Very hot temperatures were experienced in parts of southeast Arizona on July 10th, 11th and 12th with record high temperatures tied or set in some locations. Four heat-related fatalities occurred--one in western Pima County and three on the Tohono O'odham Nation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Well above normal temperatures occurred in southeast Arizona July 10th through the 12th.  Record high temperatures include 110 degrees (tie) at Tucson International Airport and 107 degrees at Sasabe on the 10th, 110 degrees at Sells and Safford (tie), 108 at Sasabe, 107 at Willcox, 106 at Duncan (tie) and 104 at Nogales Airport on the 11th, and 111 degrees (tie) at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument and 108 at Sasabe on the 12th.   The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three adult males and one unidentified male during this time frame but exact dates are estimated.  One individual perished on the grounds of Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument on the 10th.  Three others died on the Tohono O'odham Nation--one in the vicinity of Menager's Dam on the 10th, another near Papago Farms on the 11th, and a third near San Miguel on the 12th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first two weeks of August, while eventually expanding east into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana, resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid to upper 90s each day. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area south of a weak stationary front over Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas, which only allowed for minimal mixing each afternoon. This resulted in heat indices consistently ranging from 105-110 degrees each day across North Louisiana from the afternoon of the 7th to the 11th. However, as the upper ridge moved into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana during the second week of August, afternoon temperatures climbed into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees by the afternoon of the 11th, and when combined with the high humidity, resulted in a period of excessive heat over the region.

A very large high in the upper levels of the atmosphere was sprawled across the southern two-thirds of the country for several days. This high brought three to four days of oppressive heat and humidity across southern Illinois. Cooling centers were opened at various public offices, including Carbondale city hall and health offices in Union and Williamson Counties. Afternoon heat indices peaked between 101 and 111 degrees each day from the 18th to the 21st. The heat index at Carbondale peaked at 111 degrees on the 18th, and 107 to 108 from the 19th to the 21st. Heat indices in the southeast counties were not quite as high, but still around 105 each day. Just prior to this heat wave, the remnants of Tropical Storm Barry produced a widespread soaking rain that set the stage for very high humidity levels. Dew points were in the mid 70's. Actual high temperatures were in the lower 90's.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level ridge of high pressure was anchored over Southcentral Texas into the Lower Mississippi and Tennessee Vallies July 9th and 10th, resulting in an expansive area of sinking air which allowed for afternoon temperatures to climb into the mid 90s each day. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during this time, with the resultant heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across North Louisiana. A weak cool front and associated upper level shortwave trough moved through the area during the afternoon hours on the 11th, but the slightly cooler air and lower humidities were not able to mix south through the region until the evening hours through the morning on the 12th. Thus, afternoon temperatures across North Louisiana on July 11th again rose into the mid 90s, with the resultant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level ridge of high pressure was anchored over Southcentral Texas into the Lower Mississippi and Tennessee Vallies July 9th and 10th, resulting in an expansive area of sinking air which allowed for afternoon temperatures to climb into the mid 90s each day. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during this time, with the resultant heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across Northeast Texas. A weak cool front and associated upper level shortwave trough moved through the area during the evening of the 10th through the overnight hours into the 11th, allowing for scattered showers and thunderstorms to develop and move through the region. Slightly cooler temperatures and lower humidities were observed in wake of the frontal passage across Northeast Texas on July 11th.

Early and mid July were dominated by a ridge, with hot and humid conditions most days. On July 10th, an elderly male went missing while out picking berries in the forest. He was found deceased that evening. A combination of prior health issues and the heat are blamed for his death. The high temperature at East Lynn Lake, a nearby Cooperative Observer station, was 90 degrees. Heat index values that afternoon topped out around 100 degrees.
Eight people died in Las Vegas of heat related causes.

An upper level ridge of high pressure amplified over the Southern Plains during August 7th, and expanded east into much of the Ark-La-Tex on the 8th. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, allowed afternoon temperatures to  climb into the mid and upper 90s across the Northern sections of Southwest Arkansas, including Little River, Sevier, Howard, Hempstead, and Nevada Counties. In addition, low level moisture pooled from Southeast Oklahoma and much of Southwest Arkansas near a weak stationary front, which did not allow for much mixing, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees each day.

A flat upper level ridge of high pressure over South Texas and the Northern Gulf of Mexico on August 17th began to amplify north across the Southern Plains and Ark-La-Tex region on the 18th, with this ridge lingering over the area through the 21st. Given the dry topsoil moisture conditions already in place, temperatures quickly climbed into the mid to upper 90s across North Louisiana, with additional compressional warming beneath the expanding upper level ridge contributing to temperatures climbing further in excess of 100 degrees on the 18th-21st especially over Western Louisiana. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during the period, resulting in oppressively hot conditions, with heat indices ranging from 105 to 110 degrees each day. Slightly less humid conditions were observed on August 22nd as the upper ridge retreated back to the west into New Mexico, allowing for a weak upper trough and associated surface front to enter the area, and focusing an increase in isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms.

A flat upper level ridge of high pressure over South Texas and the Northern Gulf of Mexico on August 17th began to amplify north across the Southern Plains and Ark-La-Tex region on the 18th, with this ridge lingering over the area through the 21st. Given the dry topsoil moisture conditions already in place, temperatures quickly climbed into the mid to upper 90s across North Louisiana, with additional compressional warming beneath the expanding upper level ridge contributing to temperatures climbing further in excess of 100 degrees on the 18th-21st especially over Western Louisiana. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during the period, resulting in oppressively hot conditions, with heat indices ranging from 105 to 110 degrees each day. Slightly less humid conditions were observed on August 22nd as the upper ridge retreated back to the west into New Mexico, allowing for a weak upper trough and associated surface front to enter the area, and focusing an increase in isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built back east into the Southern Plains and portions of the Four State Region during the morning hours of August 26th, with the sinking air beneath the ridge resulting in compressional heating which allowed afternoon temperatures that day to climb into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees across all of East Texas. Dewpoints were not able to mix out much during the afternoon, and when combined with these very hot temperatures, heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees across much of East Texas. A complex of showers and thunderstorms shifted south across Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas and weakened as it entered East Texas shortly after daybreak on the 27th, which reinforced a weak cold front south through the area, bringing some relief to the heat in the form of cooler temperatures and slightly drier air.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper high pressure area that was centered over the four corners region built westward into central California between August 14 and 16. This resulted in widespread triple digit heat across the San Joaquin Valley, southern Sierra foothills and Kern County Deserts during this time frame. Excessive heat highlights were issued for the San Joaquin Valley and southern Sierra foothills as a result. A cooling trend then took place on August 16 and 17 as an upper trough pushes into the Pacific Northwest and broke down the large area of high pressure.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 103 and 108 degrees at most locations between August 14 and August 16.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure amplified over the Southern Plains during August 7th, and expanded east into much of the Ark-La-Tex on the 8th. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, allowed afternoon temperatures to climb into the mid and upper 90s across McCurtain County Oklahoma. In addition, low level moisture pooled from Southeast Oklahoma and much of Southwest Arkansas near a weak stationary front, which did not allow for much mixing, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees each day.

An upper level ridge of high pressure amplified over the Southern Plains during August 7th, and expanded east into much of the Ark-La-Tex on the 8th. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, allowed afternoon temperatures to climb into the mid and upper 90s across much of Southwest Arkansas, including Lafayette, Columbia, and Union Counties. In addition, low level moisture continued to pool from Southeast Oklahoma and much of Southwest Arkansas near a weak stationary front, which did not allow for much mixing, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees each day. However, the heat intensified by the afternoon of August 11th as the center of the upper level ridge moved east into Southwest Arkansas, where the dewpoints were not able to mix out/lower, allowing for heat indices to exceed 110 degrees and resulting in an Excessive Heat Warning to be issued for all of Southwest Arkansas with the exception of Miller County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure in place across the Southern Plains during the first week of August expanded east into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana during the second week of the month, resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area where low level moisture continued to pool from Southeast Oklahoma and much of Southwest Arkansas near a weak stationary front, and did not allow for much mixing. This resulted in a period of excessive heat, with heat indices consistently ranging from 110-113 degrees across much of Southwest Arkansas from the afternoon of the 11th through the 13th. A weak surface front moved through the area on the 14th, bringing about isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms and eventually, lower humidity, providing brief relief from the heat.

A flat upper level ridge of high pressure over South Texas and the Northern Gulf of Mexico on August 17th began to amplify north across the Southern Plains and Ark-La-Tex region on the 18th, with this ridge lingering over the area through the 21st. Given the dry topsoil moisture conditions already in place, temperatures quickly climbed into the mid 90s across much of Southeast Oklahoma, with additional compressional warming beneath the expanding upper level ridge contributing to temperatures climbing further into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across McCurtain County on the 18th-21st. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during the period, resulting in oppressively hot conditions, with heat indices ranging from 106 to 110 degrees each day. Slightly cooler conditions were observed on August 22nd as the upper ridge retreated back to the west into New Mexico, allowing for a weak upper trough and associated surface front to enter the area, focusing an increase in isolated to widely scattered showers and thunderstorms.

This resulted in widespread triple digit heat across the San Joaquin Valley, southern Sierra foothills and Kern County Deserts during this time frame. Excessive heat highlights were issued for the San Joaquin Valley and southern Sierra foothills as a result. A cooling trend then took place on August 16 and 17 as an upper trough pushes into the Pacific Northwest and broke down the large area of high pressure.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 103 and 108 degrees at most locations between August 14 and August 16.

A cooling trend then took place on August 16 and 17 as an upper trough pushes into the Pacific Northwest and broke down the large area of high pressure.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 100 and 105 degrees at most locations on August 15 and August 16.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper high pressure area that was centered over the four corners region built westward into central California between August 14 and 16. This resulted in widespread triple digit heat across the San Joaquin Valley, southern Sierra foothills and Kern County Deserts during this time frame. Excessive heat highlights were issued for the San Joaquin Valley and southern Sierra foothills as a result. A cooling trend then took place on August 16 and 17 as an upper trough pushes into the Pacific Northwest and broke down the large area of high pressure.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 100 and 105 degrees at most locations on August 15 and August 16.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure amplified over the Southern Plains during August 7th, and expanded east into much of the Ark-La-Tex on the 8th. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, allowed afternoon temperatures to climb into the mid and upper 90s across much of Southwest Arkansas, including Lafayette, Columbia, and Union Counties. In addition, low level moisture continued to pool from Southeast Oklahoma and much of Southwest Arkansas near a weak stationary front, which did not allow for much mixing, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees each day. However, the heat intensified by the afternoon of August 11th as the center of the upper level ridge moved east into Southwest Arkansas, where the dewpoints were not able to mix out/lower, allowing for heat indices to exceed 110 degrees and resulting in an Excessive Heat Warning to be issued for all of Southwest Arkansas with the exception of Miller County.

An upper level ridge of high pressure in place across the Southern Plains during the first week of August expanded east into much of the Ark-La-Tex during the second week of the month. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, allowed afternoon temperatures to climb into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees across Miller County Arkansas, and occurred over an area where low level moisture continued to pool from Southeast Oklahoma and much of Southwest Arkansas near a weak stationary front that did not allow for much mixing. This resulted in heat indices ranging from 105-108 degrees across Miller County Arkansas from August 7th-13th, before a weak surface front moved through the area during the daytime hours on the 14th. This allowed for temperatures falling back into the lower 90s on the 14th.

An upper level ridge of high pressure in place across the Southern Plains during the first week of August expanded east into much of the Ark-La-Tex during the second week of the month. After a brief respite in the oppressive heat and humidity on August 9th, temperatures on the 10th and 11th again climbed back into the mid and upper 90s.  This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area where low level moisture continued to pool from Southeast Oklahoma and much of Southwest Arkansas near a weak stationary front, and did not allow for much mixing. This resulted in heat indices again ranging from 105-110 degrees across McCurtain County Oklahoma on the 10th and exceeded 110 degrees across much of the county on the 11th, which continued through the 13th. Thus, an Excessive Heat Warning was issued for much of Southeast Oklahoma during the mid-afternoon of the 11th.

A flat upper level ridge of high pressure over South Texas and the Northern Gulf of Mexico on August 17th began to amplify north across the Southern Plains and Ark-La-Tex region on the 18th, with this ridge lingering over the area through the 21st. Given the dry topsoil moisture conditions already in place, temperatures quickly climbed into the mid to upper 90s across East Texas, with additional compressional warming beneath the expanding upper level ridge contributing to temperatures climbing further in excess of 100 degrees on the 18th-21st. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during the period, resulting in oppressively hot conditions, with heat indices ranging from 105 to 109 degrees each day. Slightly less humid conditions were observed on August 22nd as the upper ridge retreated back to the west into New Mexico, allowing for a weak upper trough and associated surface front to enter the area, focusing an increase in isolated to widely scattered showers and thunderstorms.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built back east into the Southern Plains and portions of the Four State Region during the morning hours of August 26th, with the sinking air beneath the ridge resulting in compressional heating which allowed afternoon temperatures that day to climb into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees across all of East Texas. Dewpoints were not able to mix out much during the afternoon, and when combined with these very hot temperatures, heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees across much of East Texas. A complex of showers and thunderstorms shifted south across Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas and weakened as it entered East Texas shortly after daybreak on the 27th, which reinforced a weak cold front south through the area, bringing some relief to the heat in the form of cooler temperatures and slightly drier air.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A heat wave developed August 2-4 with high temperatures 98 to 102F for Inland Empire and 115F at Palm Springs on Sunday August 2. The heat peaked on August 5-6, 2019. The impact was mainly the Inland Empire and Coachella Valley. On August 5 and 6, the Inland Empire cities reached 103 to 107 both days and on Monday August 5, Palm Springs recorded its hottest temperature of the year at 121F. Ocotillo Wells and Thermal were both 120F. Palm Springs was 116F on Sunday August 4.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Palm Springs reach 115F on August 2, 116F on August 4 and the hottest day of the summer at 121F on August 5. On August 5 Thermal and Ocotillo Wells reached 120F.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure in place across the Southern Plains during the first week of August expanded east into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana during the second week of the month, resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area where low level moisture continued to pool from Southeast Oklahoma and much of Southwest Arkansas near a weak stationary front, and did not allow for much mixing. This resulted in a period of excessive heat, with heat indices consistently ranging from 110-113 degrees across much of Southwest Arkansas from the afternoon of the 11th through the 13th. A weak surface front moved through the area on the 14th, bringing about isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms and eventually, lower humidity, providing brief relief from the heat.

A large area of high pressure dominated over the region between August 25 and 27. Temperatures across the San Joaquin Valley and southern Sierra foothills nudged upward back into the triple digits by August 25 and prompted the issuance of a Heat Advisory for the San Joaquin Valley and southern Sierra foothills by the 27th as well as an Excessive Heat Warning for the Kern County Deserts where highs approached 110 degrees. The high slowly broke down on August 28 and 29 giving way to a cooling trend across the area although temperatures remained above seasonal normals for late August as they were for much of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 101 and 106 degrees at most locations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure in place across the Southern Plains during the first week of August expanded east into much of the Ark-La-Tex during the second week of the month. After a brief respite in the oppressive heat and humidity on August 9th, temperatures on the 10th and 11th again climbed back into the mid and upper 90s across the northern sections of Southwest Arkansas. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area where low level moisture continued to pool from Southeast Oklahoma and much of Southwest Arkansas near a weak stationary front, and did not allow for much mixing. This resulted in heat indices again ranging from 105-110 degrees across Little River, Sevier, Howard, Hempstead, and Nevada Counties in Southwest Arkansas on the 10th, which exceeded 110 degrees across much of these areas on the 11th and continued through the 13th. Thus, an Excessive Heat Warning was issued for much of Southwest Arkansas during the mid-afternoon of the 11th.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A heat wave developed August 2-4 with high temperatures 98 to 102F for Inland Empire and 115F at Palm Springs on Sunday August 2. The heat peaked on August 5-6, 2019. The impact was mainly the Inland Empire and Coachella Valley. On August 5 and 6, the Inland Empire cities reached 103 to 107 both days and on Monday August 5, Palm Springs recorded its hottest temperature of the year at 121F. Ocotillo Wells and Thermal were both 120F. Palm Springs was 116F on Sunday August 4.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Inland Empire was 98 to 102F on August 2 and peaked to 103 to 107 on August 5 and 6th. On Tuesday, San Bernardino and Lake Elsinore (RTP) reached 106F and Riverside Airport topped out at 105F. Chino airport reached 104F and Ontario Airport 103F.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat indices topping out in the low to mid 90s from early to mid afternoon led to a 2 year old toddler passing away from hyperthermia as she climbed into a vehicle for an extended period of time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A two year old toddler passed away from hyperthermia in a vehicle as heat indices warmed into the low to mid 90s.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 101 and 106 degrees at most locations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure in place across the Southern Plains during the first week of August expanded east into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana during the second week of the month, resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area where low level moisture continued to pool from Southeast Oklahoma and much of Southwest Arkansas near a weak stationary front, and did not allow for much mixing. This resulted in a period of excessive heat, with heat indices consistently ranging from 110-113 degrees across much of Southwest Arkansas from the afternoon of the 11th through the 13th. A weak surface front moved through the area on the 14th, bringing about isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms and eventually, lower humidity, providing brief relief from the heat.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first two weeks of August, while eventually expanding east into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana, resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees each day. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area south of a weak stationary front over Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas, which only allowed for minimal mixing each afternoon. This resulted in heat indices consistently ranging from 105-110 degrees each day across Northeast Texas from the afternoon of the 7th to the 13th. A weak surface front moved through the area on the 14th, bringing about isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms and eventually, lower humidity, providing brief relief from the heat.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A flat upper level ridge of high pressure over South Texas and the Northern Gulf of Mexico on August 17th began to amplify north across the Southern Plains and Ark-La-Tex region on the 18th, with this ridge lingering over the area through the 21st. Given the dry topsoil moisture conditions already in place, temperatures quickly climbed into the mid to upper 90s across East Texas, with additional compressional warming beneath the expanding upper level ridge contributing to temperatures climbing further in excess of 100 degrees on the 18th-21st. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during the period, resulting in oppressively hot conditions, with heat indices ranging from 105 to 109 degrees each day. Slightly less humid conditions were observed on August 22nd as the upper ridge retreated back to the west into New Mexico, allowing for a weak upper trough and associated surface front to enter the area, focusing an increase in isolated to widely scattered showers and thunderstorms.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built back east into the Southern Plains and portions of the Four State Region during the morning hours of August 26th, with the sinking air beneath the ridge resulting in compressional heating which allowed afternoon temperatures that day to climb into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees across all of East Texas. Dewpoints were not able to mix out much during the afternoon, and when combined with these very hot temperatures, heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees across much of East Texas. A complex of showers and thunderstorms shifted south across Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas and weakened as it entered East Texas shortly after daybreak on the 27th, which reinforced a weak cold front south through the area, bringing some relief to the heat in the form of cooler temperatures and slightly drier air.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An uppper level high centered over western Arizona ushered in hot weather to parts of Southern California. The deserts and inland valleys experienced much warmer than normal temperatures, with August 14th and 15th being the hottest days of the event. Temperatures were hottest in the Coachella Valley, where Thermal reached 120 degrees and Palm Springs reached 119 on August 15th. Ramona reached 100 degrees and Lake Elsinore reached 105 degrees on August 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many locations in the High Desert recorded high temperatures in excess of 100 degrees on August 14th and 15th. Hesperia reached a high of 103 degrees and Apple Valley reached a high of 104 degrees on August 15th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An uppper level high centered over western Arizona ushered in hot weather to parts of Southern California. The deserts and inland valleys experienced much warmer than normal temperatures, with August 14th and 15th being the hottest days of the event. Temperatures were hottest in the Coachella Valley, where Thermal reached 120 degrees and Palm Springs reached 119 on August 15th. Ramona reached 100 degrees and Lake Elsinore reached 105 degrees on August 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous locations in the Coachella Valley experienced extreme high temperatures on August 14th and 15th. Thermal Airport recorded a high temperature of 120 degrees, and Palm Springs Airport recorded a high temperature of 119 degrees on August 15th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first two weeks of August, while eventually expanding east into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana, resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid to upper 90s each day. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area south of a weak stationary front over Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas, which only allowed for minimal mixing each afternoon. This resulted in heat indices consistently ranging from 105-110 degrees each day across North Louisiana from the afternoon of the 7th to the 11th. However, as the upper ridge moved into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana during the second week of August, afternoon temperatures climbed into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees by the afternoon of the 11th, and when combined with the high humidity, resulted in a period of excessive heat over the region.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first two weeks of August, while eventually expanding east into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana, resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid to upper 90s each day. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area south of a weak stationary front over Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas, which only allowed for minimal mixing each afternoon. This resulted in heat indices consistently ranging from 105-110 degrees each day across North Louisiana (including Sabine Parish) from the afternoon of the 7th to the 14th. A weak surface front moved through the area during the afternoon and evening of the 14th, and focused isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms across Sabine Parish, before eventually lower humidities spread into the area on the 15th, providing a brief respite from the oppressive heat.

An upper level ridge of high pressure over the Southern Plains eventually shifted east and became centered over Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana during the second week of August, resulting in a period of excessive heat as afternoon temperatures climbed into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees from the 11th to the 14th. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area south of a weak stationary front over Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas, which only allowed for minimal mixing each afternoon. This resulted in heat indices consistently ranging from 110-114 degrees each day across much of North Louisiana. The approach of a weak surface front, increased cloud, and isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms during the 14th resulted in slightly cooler temperatures and lower heat indices over the region.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built back east into the Southern Plains and portions of the Four State Region during the morning hours of August 26th, with the sinking air beneath the ridge resulting in compressional heating which allowed afternoon temperatures that day to climb into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees across all of East Texas. Dewpoints were not able to mix out much during the afternoon, and when combined with these very hot temperatures, heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees across much of East Texas. A complex of showers and thunderstorms shifted south across Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas and weakened as it entered East Texas shortly after daybreak on the 27th, which reinforced a weak cold front south through the area, bringing some relief to the heat in the form of cooler temperatures and slightly drier air.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure built in across the Southern Plains during the first two weeks of August, while eventually expanding east into Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana, resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees each day. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area south of a weak stationary front over Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas, which only allowed for minimal mixing each afternoon. This resulted in heat indices consistently ranging from 105-110 degrees each day across Northeast Texas from the afternoon of the 7th to the 13th. A weak surface front moved through the area on the 14th, bringing about isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms and eventually, lower humidity, providing brief relief from the heat.

A large area of high pressure dominated over the region between August 25 and 27. Temperatures across the San Joaquin Valley and southern Sierra foothills nudged upward back into the triple digits by August 25 and prompted the issuance of a Heat Advisory for the San Joaquin Valley and southern Sierra foothills by the 27th as well as an Excessive Heat Warning for the Kern County Deserts where highs approached 110 degrees. The high slowly broke down on August 28 and 29 giving way to a cooling trend across the area although temperatures remained above seasonal normals for late August as they were for much of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 104 and 109 degrees at most locations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat indices peaked between 105 and 112 degrees across southern Illinois during the afternoon hours. From Marion southward to Metropolis and Cairo, the heat index peaked at or just above 110 degrees. Elsewhere across southern Illinois, the peak heat index was from 105 to 109. Actual air temperatures reached the lower 90's from Marion southward, and generally around 90 elsewhere. Dew points were in the upper 70's to near 80, which resulted in the very high heat indices. At mid levels of the atmosphere, a large ridge of high pressure dominated the southern half of the United States. A weak surface warm front over the lower Ohio Valley caused dew points to pool into the upper 70's to near 80.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An uppper level high centered over western Arizona ushered in hot weather to parts of Southern California. The deserts and inland valleys experienced much warmer than normal temperatures, with August 14th and 15th being the hottest days of the event. Temperatures were hottest in the Coachella Valley, where Thermal reached 120 degrees and Palm Springs reached 119 on August 15th. Ramona reached 100 degrees and Lake Elsinore reached 105 degrees on August 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many locations throughout the Inland Empire reported temperatures in excess of 100 degrees on August 14th and 15th. The warmest temperatures were recorded at Lake Elsinore and San Jacinto (105 on the 14th and 104 on the 14th).

Ramona reached 100 degrees and Lake Elsinore reached 105 degrees on August 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many locations in the San Diego County deserts recorded extreme temperatures August 14th-15th. Borrego Springs recorded a high temperature of 115 degrees, and Ocotillo Wells recorded a high temperature of 119 degrees on August 15th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many locations in the San Diego County valleys experienced extreme temperatures on August 14th and 15th. Valley Center recorded a high temperature of 101 degrees, and Ramona and Alpine recorded a high temperature of 99 on August 15th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A flat upper level ridge of high pressure over South Texas and the Northern Gulf of Mexico on August 17th began to amplify north across the Southern Plains and Ark-La-Tex region on the 18th, with this ridge lingering over the area through the 21st. Given the dry topsoil moisture conditions already in place, temperatures quickly climbed into the mid to upper 90s across East Texas, with additional compressional warming beneath the expanding upper level ridge contributing to temperatures climbing further in excess of 100 degrees on the 18th-21st. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during the period, resulting in oppressively hot conditions, with heat indices ranging from 105 to 109 degrees each day. Slightly less humid conditions were observed on August 22nd as the upper ridge retreated back to the west into New Mexico, allowing for a weak upper trough and associated surface front to enter the area, focusing an increase in isolated to widely scattered showers and thunderstorms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure that had been dominant across the Southern Plains and Lower Mississippi Valley during the first two weeks of August, and brought about an extended period of oppressive heat to North Louisiana, finally had begun to weaken by the evening and overnight hours of the 13th through the 14th, when a weak shortwave trough dropped southeast into the area, allowing for a weak surface front to push south into the region. This front focused isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms across portions of North Louisiana on the 14th, but before they developed and spread into the region, temperatures had managed to climb into the lower to mid 90s, and when combined with the high humidity, resulted in heat indices near 105 degrees. This front and needed rainfall brought about cooler conditions and eventually slightly lower humidities to the region for the 15th.

An upper level ridge of high pressure that had been dominant across the Southern Plains and Lower Mississippi Valley during the first two weeks of August, and brought about an extended period of oppressive heat to North Louisiana, finally had begun to weaken by the evening and overnight hours of the 13th through the 14th, when a weak shortwave trough dropped southeast into the area, allowing for a weak surface front to push south into the region. This front focused isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms across portions of North Louisiana on the 14th, but before they developed and spread into the region, temperatures had managed to climb into the lower to mid 90s, and when combined with the high humidity, resulted in heat indices near 105 degrees. This front and needed rainfall brought about cooler conditions and eventually slightly lower humidities to the region for the 15th.

This front focused isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms across portions of North Louisiana on the 14th, but before they developed and spread into the region, temperatures had managed to climb into the lower to mid 90s, and when combined with the high humidity, resulted in heat indices near 105 degrees. This front and needed rainfall brought about cooler conditions and eventually slightly lower humidities to the region for the 15th.

An upper level ridge of high pressure that had been dominant across much of the Southern Plains and Lower Mississippi Valley finally began to retreat back to the west into New Mexico during the early morning hours of August 22nd, although the eastward extension of this ridge lingered over portions of Oklahoma and North Texas. However, early morning temperatures only briefly cooled into the mid and upper 70s on the morning of the 22nd. Given the very dry topsoil moisture conditions in place, daytime temperatures on the 22nd quickly climbed into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across much of East Texas and North Louisiana, although areas of extreme Eastern Texas and Northwest Louisiana had failed to mix out the usually high dewpoints that were in place. Thus, heat indices ranged from 105 to 108 degrees across these areas during the early and mid-afternoon afternoon hours, before scattered showers and thunderstorms developed by mid-afternoon, resulting in temperatures to cool into the 80s and lower 90s late in the day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure over the Southern Plains eventually shifted east and became centered over Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana during the second week of August, resulting in a period of excessive heat as afternoon temperatures climbed into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees from the 11th to the 14th. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area south of a weak stationary front over Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas, which only allowed for minimal mixing each afternoon. This resulted in heat indices consistently ranging from 110-114 degrees each day across much of North Louisiana. The approach of a weak surface front, increased cloud, and isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms during the 14th resulted in slightly cooler temperatures and lower heat indices over the region.

A flat upper level ridge of high pressure over South Texas and the Northern Gulf of Mexico on August 17th began to amplify north across the Southern Plains and Ark-La-Tex region on the 18th, with this ridge lingering over the area through the 21st. Given the dry topsoil moisture conditions already in place, temperatures quickly climbed into the mid to upper 90s across East Texas, with additional compressional warming beneath the expanding upper level ridge contributing to temperatures climbing further in excess of 100 degrees on the 18th-21st. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during the period, resulting in oppressively hot conditions, with heat indices ranging from 105 to 109 degrees each day. Slightly less humid conditions were observed on August 22nd as the upper ridge retreated back to the west into New Mexico, allowing for a weak upper trough and associated surface front to enter the area, focusing an increase in isolated to widely scattered showers and thunderstorms.

An upper level ridge of high pressure over the south central United States resulted in a period of unseasonably hot weather over eastern Oklahoma from the 10th through the 12th. Afternoon high temperatures in the upper 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with high humidity, resulted in afternoon heat indices each day from 110 to 115 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure centered near the Four Corners led to dangerous heat across the Phoenix area. The heat led to 13 fatalities (5 direct and 8 indirect) according to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One indirect fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender and circumstances unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure centered near the Four Corners led to dangerous heat across the Phoenix area. The heat led to 13 fatalities (5 direct and 8 indirect) according to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two fatalities (1 direct and 1 indirect) were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender and circumstances unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure that had been dominant across the Southern Plains and Lower Mississippi Valley during the first two weeks of August, and brought about an extended period of oppressive heat to North Louisiana, finally had begun to weaken by the evening and overnight hours of the 13th through the 14th, when a weak shortwave trough dropped southeast into the area, allowing for a weak surface front to push south into the region. This front focused isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms across portions of North Louisiana on the 14th, but before they developed and spread into the region, temperatures had managed to climb into the lower to mid 90s, and when combined with the high humidity, resulted in heat indices near 105 degrees. This front and needed rainfall brought about cooler conditions and eventually slightly lower humidities to the region for the 15th.

An upper level ridge of high pressure that had been dominant across much of the Southern Plains and Lower Mississippi Valley finally began to retreat back to the west into New Mexico during the early morning hours of August 22nd, although the eastward extension of this ridge lingered over portions of Oklahoma and North Texas. However, early morning temperatures only briefly cooled into the mid and upper 70s on the morning of the 22nd. Given the very dry topsoil moisture conditions in place, daytime temperatures on the 22nd quickly climbed into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across much of East Texas and North Louisiana, although areas of extreme Eastern Texas and Northwest Louisiana had failed to mix out the usually high dewpoints that were in place. Thus, heat indices ranged from 105 to 108 degrees across these areas during the early and mid-afternoon afternoon hours, before scattered showers and thunderstorms developed by mid-afternoon, resulting in temperatures to cool into the 80s and lower 90s late in the day.

Heat indices peaked between 105 and 112 degrees across southern Illinois during the afternoon hours. From Marion southward to Metropolis and Cairo, the heat index peaked at or just above 110 degrees. Elsewhere across southern Illinois, the peak heat index was from 105 to 109. Actual air temperatures reached the lower 90's from Marion southward, and generally around 90 elsewhere. Dew points were in the upper 70's to near 80, which resulted in the very high heat indices. At mid levels of the atmosphere, a large ridge of high pressure dominated the southern half of the United States. A weak surface warm front over the lower Ohio Valley caused dew points to pool into the upper 70's to near 80.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure in place across the Southern Plains during the first week of August expanded east into much of the Ark-La-Tex during the second week of the month. After a brief respite in the oppressive heat and humidity on August 9th, temperatures on the 10th and 11th again climbed back into the mid and upper 90s across the northern sections of Southwest Arkansas. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area where low level moisture continued to pool from Southeast Oklahoma and much of Southwest Arkansas near a weak stationary front, and did not allow for much mixing. This resulted in heat indices again ranging from 105-110 degrees across Little River, Sevier, Howard, Hempstead, and Nevada Counties in Southwest Arkansas on the 10th, which exceeded 110 degrees across much of these areas on the 11th and continued through the 13th. Thus, an Excessive Heat Warning was issued for much of Southwest Arkansas during the mid-afternoon of the 11th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were recorded in southeast Arizona on July 15th and 16th. No heat-related fatalities were reported despite a record-tying high temperature of 110 degrees at Tucson International Airport on the 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures occurred on July 15th and 16th with respective high temperatures of 110 and 111 degrees at Organ Pipe National Monument, 109 and 108 at Sells, 108 and 110 (tied record) at Tucson International Airport, and 109 both days at the Safford Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions led to multiple days of heat warnings and advisories.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperature led to over 30 heat related calls to emergency officials over the period.

This front focused isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms across portions of North Louisiana on the 14th, but before they developed and spread into the region, temperatures had managed to climb into the lower to mid 90s, and when combined with the high humidity, resulted in heat indices near 105 degrees. This front and needed rainfall brought about cooler conditions and eventually slightly lower humidities to the region for the 15th.

An upper level ridge of high pressure that had been dominant across much of the Southern Plains and Lower Mississippi Valley finally began to retreat back to the west into New Mexico during the early morning hours of August 22nd, although the eastward extension of this ridge lingered over portions of Oklahoma and North Texas. However, early morning temperatures only briefly cooled into the mid and upper 70s on the morning of the 22nd. Given the very dry topsoil moisture conditions in place, daytime temperatures on the 22nd quickly climbed into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across much of East Texas and North Louisiana, although areas of extreme Eastern Texas and Northwest Louisiana had failed to mix out the usually high dewpoints that were in place. Thus, heat indices ranged from 105 to 108 degrees across these areas during the early and mid-afternoon afternoon hours, before scattered showers and thunderstorms developed by mid-afternoon, resulting in temperatures to cool into the 80s and lower 90s late in the day.

Heat indices peaked between 105 and 112 degrees across southern Illinois during the afternoon hours. From Marion southward to Metropolis and Cairo, the heat index peaked at or just above 110 degrees. Elsewhere across southern Illinois, the peak heat index was from 105 to 109. Actual air temperatures reached the lower 90's from Marion southward, and generally around 90 elsewhere. Dew points were in the upper 70's to near 80, which resulted in the very high heat indices. At mid levels of the atmosphere, a large ridge of high pressure dominated the southern half of the United States. A weak surface warm front over the lower Ohio Valley caused dew points to pool into the upper 70's to near 80.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure in place across the Southern Plains during the first week of August expanded east into much of the Ark-La-Tex during the second week of the month. After a brief respite in the oppressive heat and humidity on August 9th, temperatures on the 10th and 11th again climbed back into the mid and upper 90s across the northern sections of Southwest Arkansas. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area where low level moisture continued to pool from Southeast Oklahoma and much of Southwest Arkansas near a weak stationary front, and did not allow for much mixing. This resulted in heat indices again ranging from 105-110 degrees across Little River, Sevier, Howard, Hempstead, and Nevada Counties in Southwest Arkansas on the 10th, which exceeded 110 degrees across much of these areas on the 11th and continued through the 13th. Thus, an Excessive Heat Warning was issued for much of Southwest Arkansas during the mid-afternoon of the 11th.

A flat upper level ridge of high pressure over South Texas and the Northern Gulf of Mexico on August 17th began to amplify north across the Southern Plains and Ark-La-Tex region on the 18th, with this ridge lingering over the area through the 21st. Given the dry topsoil moisture conditions already in place, temperatures quickly climbed into the mid to upper 90s across North Louisiana, with additional compressional warming beneath the expanding upper level ridge contributing to temperatures climbing further in excess of 100 degrees on the 18th-21st especially over Western Louisiana. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during the period, resulting in oppressively hot conditions, with heat indices ranging from 105 to 110 degrees each day. Slightly less humid conditions were observed on August 22nd as the upper ridge retreated back to the west into New Mexico, allowing for a weak upper trough and associated surface front to enter the area, and focusing an increase in isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms.

An upper level ridge of high pressure over the Southern Plains eventually shifted east and became centered over Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana during the second week of August, resulting in a period of excessive heat as afternoon temperatures climbed into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees from the 11th to the 14th. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area south of a weak stationary front over Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas, which only allowed for minimal mixing each afternoon. This resulted in heat indices consistently ranging from 110-114 degrees each day across much of North Louisiana. The approach of a weak surface front, increased cloud, and isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms during the 14th resulted in slightly cooler temperatures and lower heat indices over the region.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built back east into the Southern Plains and portions of the Four State Region during the morning hours of August 26th, with the sinking air beneath the ridge resulting in compressional heating which allowed afternoon temperatures that day to climb into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees across Western Louisiana. Dewpoints were not able to mix out much during the afternoon, and when combined with these very hot temperatures, heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees across much of Western Louisiana. A complex of showers and thunderstorms shifted south across Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas and weakened as it entered North Louisiana shortly after daybreak on the 27th, which reinforced a weak cold front south through the area, bringing some relief to the heat in the form of cooler temperatures and slightly drier air.

Heat indices peaked from 105 to 109 degrees in the Tennessee border counties during the afternoon. Actual air temperatures were in the lower to mid 90's. Dew points in the lower to mid 70's resulted in the high heat indices. A thunderstorm complex over southern Illinois during the early part of the day helped to cool places further north in Kentucky. Elsewhere, high pressure in the mid levels of the atmosphere contributed to  dangerous levels of heat and humidity in the Tennessee border counties.

Slightly less humid conditions were observed on August 22nd as the upper ridge retreated back to the west into New Mexico, allowing for a weak upper trough and associated surface front to enter the area, and focusing an increase in isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms.

An upper level ridge of high pressure over the Southern Plains eventually shifted east and became centered over Southwest Arkansas and North Louisiana during the second week of August, resulting in a period of excessive heat as afternoon temperatures climbed into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees from the 11th to the 14th. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, occurred over an area south of a weak stationary front over Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas, which only allowed for minimal mixing each afternoon. This resulted in heat indices consistently ranging from 110-114 degrees each day across much of North Louisiana. The approach of a weak surface front, increased cloud, and isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms during the 14th resulted in slightly cooler temperatures and lower heat indices over the region.

This resulted in heat indices consistently ranging from 110-114 degrees each day across much of North Louisiana. The approach of a weak surface front, increased cloud, and isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms during the 14th resulted in slightly cooler temperatures and lower heat indices over the region.

An upper level ridge of high pressure that had been dominant across much of the Southern Plains and Lower Mississippi Valley finally began to retreat back to the west into New Mexico during the early morning hours of August 22nd, although the eastward extension of this ridge lingered over portions of Oklahoma and North Texas. However, early morning temperatures only briefly cooled into the mid and upper 70s on the morning of the 22nd. Given the very dry topsoil moisture conditions in place, daytime temperatures on the 22nd quickly climbed into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across much of East Texas and North Louisiana, although areas of extreme Eastern Texas and Northwest Louisiana had failed to mix out the usually high dewpoints that were in place. Thus, heat indices ranged from 105 to 108 degrees across these areas during the early and mid-afternoon afternoon hours, before scattered showers and thunderstorms developed by mid-afternoon, resulting in temperatures to cool into the 80s and lower 90s late in the day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures warmed into the middle to upper 90s with dew points in the middle to upper 70s. This resulted in heat index values of around 110 in northwest Alabama and 105-110 in north central and northeast Alabama.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index reached 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures warmed into the middle to upper 90s with dew points in the middle to upper 70s. This resulted in heat index values of around 110 in northwest Alabama and 105-110 in north central and northeast Alabama.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index reached 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure that had been dominant across the Southern Plains and Lower Mississippi Valley during the first two weeks of August, and brought about an extended period of oppressive heat to North Louisiana, finally had begun to weaken by the evening and overnight hours of the 13th through the 14th, when a weak shortwave trough dropped southeast into the area, allowing for a weak surface front to push south into the region. This front focused isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms across portions of North Louisiana on the 14th, but before they developed and spread into the region, temperatures had managed to climb into the lower to mid 90s, and when combined with the high humidity, resulted in heat indices near 105 degrees. This front and needed rainfall brought about cooler conditions and eventually slightly lower humidities to the region for the 15th.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built back east into the Southern Plains and portions of the Four State Region during the morning hours of August 26th, with the sinking air beneath the ridge resulting in compressional heating which allowed afternoon temperatures that day to climb into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees across Western Louisiana. Dewpoints were not able to mix out much during the afternoon, and when combined with these very hot temperatures, heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees across much of Western Louisiana. A complex of showers and thunderstorms shifted south across Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas and weakened as it entered North Louisiana shortly after daybreak on the 27th, which reinforced a weak cold front south through the area, bringing some relief to the heat in the form of cooler temperatures and slightly drier air.

Heat indices peaked from 105 to 109 degrees in the Tennessee border counties during the afternoon. Actual air temperatures were in the lower to mid 90's. Dew points in the lower to mid 70's resulted in the high heat indices. A thunderstorm complex over southern Illinois during the early part of the day helped to cool places further north in Kentucky. Elsewhere, high pressure in the mid levels of the atmosphere contributed to  dangerous levels of heat and humidity in the Tennessee border counties.

Heat indices peaked around 105 degrees during the afternoon from Doniphan to Poplar Bluff to Charleston. Actual air temperatures were in the lower to mid 90's. Dew points in the lower to mid 70's resulted in the high heat indices. A thunderstorm complex during the early part of the day helped to cool places further north in Missouri. Elsewhere, high pressure in the mid levels of the atmosphere continued to produce dangerous levels of heat and humidity near the Arkansas border.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A flat upper level ridge of high pressure over South Texas and the Northern Gulf of Mexico on August 17th began to amplify north across the Southern Plains and Ark-La-Tex region on the 18th, with this ridge lingering over the area through the 21st. Given the dry topsoil moisture conditions already in place, temperatures quickly climbed into the mid to upper 90s across North Louisiana, with additional compressional warming beneath the expanding upper level ridge contributing to temperatures climbing further in excess of 100 degrees on the 18th-21st especially over Western Louisiana. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during the period, resulting in oppressively hot conditions, with heat indices ranging from 105 to 110 degrees each day. Slightly less humid conditions were observed on August 22nd as the upper ridge retreated back to the west into New Mexico, allowing for a weak upper trough and associated surface front to enter the area, and focusing an increase in isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure over the south central United States resulted in a period of unseasonably hot weather over eastern Oklahoma from the 10th through the 12th. Afternoon high temperatures in the upper 90s to near 100 degrees, combined with high humidity, resulted in afternoon heat indices each day from 110 to 115 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures during the early part of the month rose to dangerous levels as the region remained under the influence of high pressure. Four heat-associated deaths (1 direct and 3 indirect) were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One indirect fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender and circumstances unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures during the early part of the month rose to dangerous levels as the region remained under the influence of high pressure. Four heat-associated deaths (1 direct and 3 indirect) were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One indirect fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender and circumstances unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper high pressure area that was centered over the four corners region built westward into central California between August 14 and 16. This resulted in widespread triple digit heat across the San Joaquin Valley, southern Sierra foothills and Kern County Deserts during this time frame. Excessive heat highlights were issued for the San Joaquin Valley and southern Sierra foothills as a result. A cooling trend then took place on August 16 and 17 as an upper trough pushes into the Pacific Northwest and broke down the large area of high pressure.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 103 and 108 degrees at most locations between August 14 and August 16.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure built back east into the Southern Plains and portions of the Four State Region during the morning hours of August 26th, with the sinking air beneath the ridge resulting in compressional heating which allowed afternoon temperatures that day to climb into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees across Southwest Arkansas. Dewpoints were not able to mix out much during the afternoon, and when combined with these very hot temperatures, heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees across much of Southwest Arkansas. A complex of showers and thunderstorms shifted south across Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas during the pre-dawn hours on the 27th, which reinforced a weak cold front south through the area, bringing some relief to the heat in the form of cooler temperatures and slightly drier air.

Heat indices peaked around 105 degrees during the afternoon from Doniphan to Poplar Bluff to Charleston. Actual air temperatures were in the lower to mid 90's. Dew points in the lower to mid 70's resulted in the high heat indices. A thunderstorm complex during the early part of the day helped to cool places further north in Missouri. Elsewhere, high pressure in the mid levels of the atmosphere continued to produce dangerous levels of heat and humidity near the Arkansas border.

An upper level ridge of high pressure amplified over the Southern Plains during August 7th, and expanded east into much of the Ark-La-Tex on the 8th. This ridge, which resulted in sinking air that compressed atop a dry ground, allowed afternoon temperatures to  climb into the mid and upper 90s across the Northern sections of Southwest Arkansas, including Little River, Sevier, Howard, Hempstead, and Nevada Counties. In addition, low level moisture pooled from Southeast Oklahoma and much of Southwest Arkansas near a weak stationary front, which did not allow for much mixing, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees each day.

Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during the period, resulting in oppressively hot conditions, with heat indices ranging from 105 to 110 degrees each day. Slightly cooler conditions were observed on August 22nd as the upper ridge retreated back to the west into New Mexico, allowing for a weak upper trough and associated surface front to enter the area, focusing an increase in isolated to scattered showers and thunderstorms.

An upper level ridge of high pressure that had been dominant across much of the Southern Plains and Lower Mississippi Valley finally began to retreat back to the west into New Mexico during the early morning hours of August 22nd, although the eastward extension of this ridge lingered over portions of Oklahoma and North Texas. However, early morning temperatures only briefly cooled into the mid and upper 70s on the morning of the 22nd. Given the very dry topsoil moisture conditions in place, daytime temperatures on the 22nd quickly climbed into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across much of East Texas and North Louisiana, although areas of extreme Eastern Texas and Northwest Louisiana had failed to mix out the usually high dewpoints that were in place. Thus, heat indices ranged from 105 to 108 degrees across these areas during the early and mid-afternoon afternoon hours, before scattered showers and thunderstorms developed by mid-afternoon, resulting in temperatures to cool into the 80s and lower 90s late in the day.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built back east into the Southern Plains and portions of the Four State Region during the morning hours of August 26th, with the sinking air beneath the ridge resulting in compressional heating which allowed afternoon temperatures that day to climb into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees across Southeast Oklahoma. Dewpoints were not able to mix out much during the afternoon, and when combined with these very hot temperatures, heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees across much of Southeast Oklahoma, including McCurtain County. A complex of showers and thunderstorms shifted south across Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas during the pre-dawn hours on the 27th, which reinforced a weak cold front south through the area, bringing some relief to the heat in the form of cooler temperatures and slightly drier air.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built back east into the Southern Plains and portions of the Four State Region during the morning hours of August 26th, with the sinking air beneath the ridge resulting in compressional heating which allowed afternoon temperatures that day to climb into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees across all of East Texas. Dewpoints were not able to mix out much during the afternoon, and when combined with these very hot temperatures, heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees across much of East Texas. A complex of showers and thunderstorms shifted south across Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas and weakened as it entered East Texas shortly after daybreak on the 27th, which reinforced a weak cold front south through the area, bringing some relief to the heat in the form of cooler temperatures and slightly drier air.
