Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached in much of Mohave County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached in the Colorado River Valley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure centered near the Four Corners led to well above normal temperatures and excessive heat warning conditions across the region. Four direct fatalities were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health. One of these fatalities was a 3 year old girl who was left in a hot vehicle for 2 to 3 hours as reported by local media.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One direct fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender and circumstances unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure over the Desert Southwest led to the hottest temperatures of the month with excessive heat warning conditions being met across the region. The deadly heat resulted in 9 fatalities (8 direct and 1 indirect) according to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One direct fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender and circumstances unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Afternoon heat indices between 105 and 110 degrees occurred across most of North and Central Texas during the second week of August 2019.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values between 105 and 110 degrees occurred across the county during the afternoon hours of August 7 through August 13 2019. Denton County Public Health reported 13 cases on Heat Related Illnesses during this period. Most of the cases were heat exhaustion.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Afternoon heat indices between 105 and 112 degrees occurred across much of the region from August 17 through August 21, 2019.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values between 105 and 112 degrees occurred across the county during the afternoon hours from Saturday August 17 to Wednesday August 21 of 2019. Denton County Public Health reported 7 cases on Heat Related Illnesses during this period. Most of the cases were heat exhaustion.

Strong high pressure aloft across central Arizona led to continued hot temperatures, allowing high temperatures in the greater Phoenix area to climb in excess of 105 degrees on Thursday July 18th. Although high temperatures did not reach to excessive heat warning thresholds, the heat was significant enough to lead to a fatality in the greater Phoenix area. A repairman working inside an enclosed attic was found dead during the evening hours in the community of Avondale. Phoenix firefighters confirmed that this was a heat-related fatality.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure aloft persisted across the greater Phoenix area on July 18th, allowing high temperatures to climb in excess of 105 degrees across the greater Phoenix area including the community of Avondale. Although the heat did not reach excessive heat warning thresholds, it was still significant enough to be dangerous. According to a report from Channel 3 news, a repairman working in the attic of an Avondale home was found unresponsive. Avondale firefighters confirmed that the repairman passed away and the death was heat related. The home he was working in was located near Avondale Boulevard and Lower Buckeye Road.

Hot September temperatures were in place when a child was accidentally left in an automobile. Temperatures were above normal but below criteria for heat advisories.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A three year old boy in San Antonio Texas was accidentally left in a car after the family returned from a T-Ball game in the early afternoon.  Air temperatures outside at the time where in the lower 90s.  The boy's body was discovered at 5 PM and was later pronounced dead.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure lingered over the Rockies and brought record setting heat to western and central Wyoming. The heat peaked on September 2nd, Labor Day. Three sites, Casper, Rock Springs and the Riverton airport, reached all-time September high temperatures with 98, 90 and 96 respectively. The Rock Springs record high was especially notable since it was the first time the station reached 90 degrees in September. Other record high temperatures included 98 in Greybull and Worland, 95 in Lander, 89 in Big Piney and 79 at Lake Yellowstone.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Casper airport reached a record high temperature of 98 degrees. This was the all time record high temperature for September.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures on September 3rd stayed just below excessive heat warning thresholds but were still sufficient to cause a fatality when a 3 year old girl was left inside a car for a few hours during the late morning. The high temperature in Phoenix was about 109 degrees. According to a KTAR news report, a 3 year old was left in a car for 2 to 3 hours during late morning; rescue teams responded to a residential area near Higley and Elliot roads in Gilbert after more than one call was received about a child in a vehicle. Responders performed CPR on the girl, who was later taken to a hospital where she died.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure lingered over the Rockies and brought record setting heat to western and central Wyoming. The heat peaked on September 2nd, Labor Day. Three sites, Casper, Rock Springs and the Riverton airport, reached all-time September high temperatures with 98, 90 and 96 respectively. The Rock Springs record high was especially notable since it was the first time the station reached 90 degrees in September. Other record high temperatures included 98 in Greybull and Worland, 95 in Lander, 89 in Big Piney and 79 at Lake Yellowstone.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rock Springs airport reached a record high temperature of 90 degrees. This was the all time record high temperature for September and the first 90 degree high temperature ever recorded at the site in the month of September.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One person died in Las Vegas of heat related causes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One person died in Las Vegas of heat related causes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An infant died in a hot car in Lake Havasu City.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An infant girl died in a hot car in Lake Havasu City. Her father faces several criminal charges.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure over the south central United States resulted in a period of unseasonably hot weather over eastern Oklahoma from the 17th through the 20th. Afternoon temperatures climbed into the upper 90s each day. These temperatures combined with high humidity resulted in heat index values from 110 to 115 degrees. At least 35 people were treated for heat-related illness in Tulsa on those dates.

An upper level ridge of high pressure over the south central United States resulted in a period of unseasonably hot weather over eastern Oklahoma from the 17th through the 20th. Afternoon temperatures climbed into the upper 90s each day. These temperatures combined with high humidity resulted in heat index values from 110 to 115 degrees. At least 35 people were treated for heat-related illness in Tulsa on those dates.

A period of unseasonably warm temperatures occurred in late September across much of southeast Georgia. On the 30th, afternoon temperatures rose into the mid and upper 90's according to several RAWS observation sites around Fort Stewart, the Hinesville Airport, and the Savannah-Hilton Head International Airport. Such temperatures produced conditions that were dangerous, especially to vulnerable populations including young children and the elderly.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Liberty County Coroner said that preliminary autopsy results were that twin 3 year old girls died of heatstroke inside a vehicle. The incident occurred in the 200 block of Augusta Way in the Griffin Park subdivision.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm humid air led to heat index readings in some areas at or above 108 degrees F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Maximum heat indices were above 108F for most observation sites in the county.

CZ_NAME: UPPER GILA RIVER AND ARAVAIPA VALLEYS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were recorded in southeast Arizona from Safford and the Tucson Metro westward on August 20th and 21st.  Several new high temperature records were established.  Two heat-related fatalities occurred in southern Pima County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures occurred on August 20th and 21st, with respective high temperatures of 111 and 113 degrees at Ajo, 109 and 111 degrees (both records) at Picacho, 111 degrees on both days at Sells, 113 degrees on both days (both were records) at Organ Pipe National Monument, 109 and 110 degrees (both records) at Tucson International Airport, 105 and 107 degrees (both records) at Sasabe, 104 and 103 degrees (both records) at Nogales International Airport, 107 degrees on both days (both were records) at Safford airport, and 109 and 108 degrees in the Gila River Valley on the San Carlos Apache Tribe reservation.  The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one adult male north of Arivaca on the 21st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat conditions briefly returned to the Colorado River Valley before finally ending for the season.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were met in the Colorado River Valley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A child dies after being left in a car.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An eighteen month old boy died after being left in a car for five hours.  The high temperature was 92 degrees but the heat index reached 113 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure strengthened across the area through the week resulting in hot temperatures and high humidity values in place across Iowa for a prolonged period of time. This led to high heat index values through much of the period, especially during the afternoon and early evening hours. Little relief was felt during the overnight hours as low temperatures remained in the 70s to around 80. Heat index values were consistently in the 105 to 115 degree range during much of the daytime period.

A three day period (June 7 to 9) with afternoon heat index values ranging from 111 to at least 124, and as high as 128 briefly (Brownsville, June 7), was a likely contributor to numerous heat exhaustion cases of undocumented immigrants in portions of the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas ranchlands. In all, 29 persons were admitted to local hospitals in the region during the period, though it was unclear if all of them had direct illnesses from the excessive heat. Information on heat-related fatalities was unknown as of this writing.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: United States Border Patrol reported 29 hospitalizations from potential heat-related illnesses between June 7 and June 9, when afternoon heat index across the Rio Grande Valley and Deep South Texas ranged, generally, from 111 to 124 degrees.  Of the 29 hospitalizations, four were directly related to heat exhaustion, on Friday June 7th.

An upper level high situated over New Mexico and Texas brought hot weather to the inland areas of Southern California. The hottest location was the Coachella Valley, where Thermal reached 117 degrees, and Palm Springs reached 116 degrees on August 21st. The San Diego Deserts were just as hot, with Ocotillo Wells reaching 117 degrees on August 21st. Up north in the High Desert, many locations were over 100 degrees, such as Apple Valley and Hesperia, where the high was 103 for both locations on August 21st. A few locations in the Inland Empire reached over 100 degrees on August 21st, such as Hemet (104 degrees) and Lake Elsinore (103 degrees). The San Diego Valleys also had hot weather, with many locations reaching 90-95 degrees and Ramona reaching 100 degrees on August 21st. The month of August was dry for all deserts and mountains making it one of the driest on record (under 10 percent of average).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many locations throughout the Coachella Valley experienced excessive heat on August 21st. Thermal reached 117 degrees and Palm Springs reached 116 degrees.

Upper level high pressure over the Great Basin brought heat, high winds and low relative humidity to Southern California. Many locations in the Inland Empire reached 100-105 degrees on the 13th. Orange and San Diego County valleys reached 90-99 degrees on the 13th. The Coachella Valley saw the highest temperatures in the region with highs topping out around 110F on Friday. Similar high temperatures occurred on the 14th. A weak Santa Ana event occurred with peak wind gusts ranging from 20-40 mph, highest in the mountains. Numerous small wildfires broke out due to the low humidity and gusty winds. One of the largest fires was the Horseshoe Fire near Hemet. It prompted evacuations of a small community near North Warren Road. No injuries or damages were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Coachella Valley experienced hot temperatures on September 13th and 14th. Palm Springs Airport and Thermal reached 110 degrees on September 13th. Similar temperatures were observed on the 14th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many locations throughout Inland Orange County observed high temperatures ranging from 90-99 degrees on September 13th and 14th. The highest temperature was 99 degrees in Lake Forest on the 14th and 99 degrees in Yorba Linda on the 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced in parts of southeast Arizona on July 10th, 11th and 12th with record high temperatures tied or set in some locations. Four heat-related fatalities occurred--one in western Pima County and three on the Tohono O'odham Nation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Well above normal temperatures occurred in southeast Arizona July 10th through the 12th.  Record high temperatures include 110 degrees (tie) at Tucson International Airport and 107 degrees at Sasabe on the 10th, 110 degrees at Sells and Safford (tie), 108 at Sasabe, 107 at Willcox, 106 at Duncan (tie) and 104 at Nogales Airport on the 11th, and 111 degrees (tie) at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument and 108 at Sasabe on the 12th.   The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three adult males and one unidentified male during this time frame but exact dates are estimated.  One individual perished on the grounds of Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument on the 10th.  Three others died on the Tohono O'odham Nation--one in the vicinity of Menager's Dam on the 10th, another near Papago Farms on the 11th, and a third near San Miguel on the 12th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures over 100 degrees were experienced in Pima County July 21st.  One heat-related fatality occurred just southwest of Tucson.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Above normal temperatures occurred in eastern Pima County on July 21st. The Tucson International Airport recorded a high temperature of 104 degrees after a morning low of 81. Green Valley topped out at 103 degrees. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one female found in the desert southeast of Ryan Field.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As an upper level ridge built in over the region, very warm and humid air moved into the area with heat indices 105+ for 5 straight days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures were in the mid to upper 90s for July 17th through 21st. Peak heat index values of 100-110 degrees were common during the afternoon and early evening for the City of St. Louis each day. There were 40 heat-related illnesses at hospital emergency departments during this event, but no heat-related deaths.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong high pressure aloft developed over the desert southwest resulting in excessive heat over the lower Arizona desert on August 20 and 21. Temperatures cooled down several degrees on Thursday the 22nd, but still remained above seasonal normal and the very hot temperatures still proved to dangerous to unprepared individuals. The high in Phoenix on Thursday reached 110 degrees, with a high of 106 reported in Apache Junction. A group of hikers from Kansas attempted to hike a trail in Lost Dutchman State Park east of Phoenix during the afternoon hours when the extreme heat forced the rescue of 44 hikers. One of the hikers called the Pinal County Sheriff's Office via 911 at 1930MST. Search and rescue units arrived and helped escort the hikers to safety. Several of the hikers were overcome by heat; two were taken out by helicopter and two others by vehicle. It was believed that the hikers belonged to a fitness group.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures developed again across the lower deserts of south central Arizona on the 22nd; the high in Phoenix reached 110 degrees and Apache Junction hit 106. Although the heat fell below excessive heat thresholds, it was still significant enough to cause problems for unprepared individuals. According to an online news article, a group of hikers from Kansas attempted to hike a trail in Lost Dutchman State Park in Apache Junction, during the afternoon and early evening hours. The hikers became overcome by the heat; at 1930MST the Pinal County Sheriff's Office received a call from one of the hikers asking for help. Search and rescue units arrived and escorted the group to safety. Several hikers were overcome by the heat and needed to be evacuated; 2 were flown out by helicopter and 2 by vehicle. The hikers were believed to be from a fitness group.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were recorded in southeast Arizona, especially from the Gila River Valley on the San Carlos Apache Tribe reservation and the Tucson Metro westward on August 14th through the 16th. Several record highs were tied or broken. One heat-related fatality occurred in the San Pedro River Valley in far southern Cochise County on August 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures occurred on August 14th and 15th with respective high temperatures of 107 (tied record) and 108 degrees at Tucson International Airport, and 108 and 107 degrees in the Gila River Valley on the San Carlos Apache Tribe reservation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were recorded in the Tucson Metro and in the western deserts of southeast Arizona on August 5th. The Tucson International Airport reached a record-setting high temperature of 109 degrees. Two heat-related fatality occurred on the Tohono O'odham Nation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Well above normal and very hot temperatures occurred on August 5th with high temperatures of 110 degrees at Ajo, Picacho, and Organ Pipe National Monument, 108 at Sells, and 109 at Tucson International Airport (record high).  The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one adult male and one unidentified male between Pisinemo and Sells on the Tohono O'odham Nation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were recorded in southeast Arizona, especially from the Gila River Valley on the San Carlos Apache Tribe reservation and the Tucson Metro westward on August 14th through the 16th. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Above normal temperatures occurred in the San Pedro River Valley of Cochise County on August 14th. High temperatures were ranged from the upper 90s in the southwest part of the county to the lower 100s in northwest sections. The warmest temperature was 105 degrees in Cascabel which tied a record for the date. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one adult female near the International Border in the vicinity of Palominas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were recorded in southeast Arizona from Safford and the Tucson Metro westward on August 20th and 21st.  Several new high temperature records were established.  Two heat-related fatalities occurred in southern Pima County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures occurred on August 20th and 21st, with respective high temperatures of 111 and 113 degrees at Ajo, 109 and 111 degrees (both records) at Picacho, 111 degrees on both days at Sells, 113 degrees on both days (both were records) at Organ Pipe National Monument, 109 and 110 degrees (both records) at Tucson International Airport, 105 and 107 degrees (both records) at Sasabe, 104 and 103 degrees (both records) at Nogales International Airport, 107 degrees on both days (both were records) at Safford airport, and 109 and 108 degrees in the Gila River Valley on the San Carlos Apache Tribe reservation. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were recorded in the Tucson Metro and in the western deserts of southeast Arizona on August 5th. The Tucson International Airport reached a record-setting high temperature of 109 degrees. Two heat-related fatality occurred on the Tohono O'odham Nation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the Desert Southwest resulted in unusually hot conditions toward the end of April with afternoon high temperatures topping out around ten degrees above normal. The abnormal heat resulted in two direct fatalities according to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One direct fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender and circumstances unavailable.
